reviews.review: A place to take your time at.. Go early in the morning, and check for festival dates, these are the best times to visit. Go with an official guide to explain what is going on. There are many priests there who for a fee will help families to prayer for loved ones with offerings that are placed in the river. They are happy for you to watch at a distance..Always go with an official guide who will explain what is going on, the cremations take place on the temple bank opposite, and may not be for some.

A unique cultural experience. We went with a local guide ($15) who did a great job explaining the Hindu tradition of burning their deceased, as well as the various temples on the grounds. There is a $10/person entrance fee, which might seem a bit steep, but was definitely worth it. Stay for the light festival at dusk.
A Must See (And I didn't even want to go). Go here See history and Wow you won't forget it ! Wear your dirty shoes here you may want rid of them later

Worth the visit! . Quite an honour to see how the Nepalese send their family off when they die. Make sure you have a guide as they explain it so much better than trying to piece together what is happening.

Get in, get out, keep your belongings close.. This came highly recommended and I was looking forward to a respectful place where the dead are sent on to their next life, what we experienced was dirty, drugged out and pushy young men trying to be our tour guide. We were here near the end of Dashain and because of this, perhaps, there was not much activity at the crematoria. The vibe here is creepy, not because bodies are being burned, but because of the people who hang out here. We left quickly. I would highly recommend coming here with a reputable guide. I would return, but only with a real guide. Enter at your own risk.
Seeing life and death as it really is. We were grateful to walk through this area.It wasn't confronting, just life as it really is. Saying goodbye and honouring loved ones.
Riverside cremations. One of the most interesting sites. Able to view the ceremony without the crowds of Varanasi. The site allowed great photo opportunity.
Interesting culture. Get to see the process of cremation clearly. Get a guide to explain the procedure to u as you see it happening just opposite the river.

Humbling experience. We sat, across the river, quietly and unobtrusively, observing various families poignant farewell to their loved ones in the traditional Hindu manner. . We regarded this as a most humbling privilege, and experience. I was particularly angered by a European tourist who placed himself immediately beside some of the bodies during the cleansing ceremony, and preparation of the bodies for cremation, and proceeded to film the events. So intrusive, disrespectful and inappropriate. Please visit, but don't intrude on others private grief.

Very humbling experience. Not what you would expect to give a 5 star review but the whole experience was very moving and humbling and in my opinion a must visit whilst in Kathmandu. So different to anything you would see in the western world, and thats surely what travel is about right?

This Is Different. Not For Everyone. Actual Hindu Cremations. We found it to be very interesting. Actual Hindu Cremations done in front of us. Cameras allowed. You stand across the Holy River and see the whole process. Please remain respectful.

An absolute must. Nepal Tours took my lady and I to witness this most sacred of experiences; families saying goodbye to their loved ones in the traditional manner. Robbie knew exactly where to go to witness this heart-filling ceremony, and did so with the utmost concern for the people involved. His explainations helped us to become part of the ceremony rather than just spectators

What an interesting place to visit. Having only ever seen such palace on television, at the ganges, to visit the real thing and be able to watch was an interesting learning curve in such a place of prayer, and sorrow. the sad part is that now the indian government has forbidden begging at tourist sites in India, these same professional beggars have now appeared in Nepal at the same sites plaguing tourists - not nice.Oh and you will get hammered by hawkers
Never seen like this before. Wow. The temple is very old and one of the most important temple of hindu religions and the river flow near to the temple which look beautiful and feel different.

Confronting but fascinating. Whether or not you will "enjoy" the riverside crematoria at the Pashupatinath Hindu temple will depend a lot on your sensitivies. Yes, it is fascinating, but also confronting, and the notion of tourists living up to photograph a solemn death ceremony for the locals does fill one with a sensation of voyeurism.
Needs a clean up. The area around is a bit suspect - understand the rituals etc. But did not really need to see it. Would not go again

Very impressive to see this local ritual. Impressive to see this local ritual of the cremation. When I was there there were many cremations going on, I have never seen anything like this it was very impressive.

Amazing and eye opening, confronting but peaceful. This is religious culture at its most eye opening.. Definately one of the must do attractions in Kathmandu. This can be confronting to see the bodies being cremated in the open but also very calming realising that the Hindu culture views death as the next step to the next life.. its great to get a good guide if you can called Richard at the front entrance, he is a Nepali that lived in London a long time and he is very knowledgable about this site and all its religious and cultural significances. Its fascinating to learn how the cremations take place and where and on what for all the various castes..and see the 400AD temples and Shivalingas and more.. The Sadhus are colorful to see, but be wary they will want money for photos and they prefer international notes! You can spend a good half day at this fascinating site but its memories stay a long time.. emjoy!

Hindu Cremation site. If you haven't been at hindu cremation sites, you've got to go to this one. Is cleaner than the ones at Varanasi, you get better view and pictures are allowed. In Varanasi they are not.

Once in a lifetime. It's a little weird/morbid to watch a funeral but it is an once in a lifetime experience. Take a guide to explain the process. If germs and smoke weird you out, bring a scarf or mask to breathe thru (they are burning bodies). This is definitely a glimpse into a cultural much different to rest of the world, so what is shocking to us, is normal and important to others. So enjoy the differences. Something you'll never forget.
Must see when visiting Kathmandu. We personally found this one of the cultural highlights in the city. Also, monkey temple is conveniently nearby.

Smoky and hot. The creamatoria was an average experience. I feel sad having to witness such events. There was so much smoke and the weather was hot. Not recommended for people who have sensitive nose and eyes.

Nice Experience. Was lucky enough to observe the cremation process of a royal family, and a orphan. The royals and riches get their rituals done in front of this building that stands out from the rest (it's beside the bridge). The rest get the rituals done further down from the bridge. Sad to see how the royal funeral spanned about 2 hours long, with so many rituals, while a poor orphan lady had hers done by a couple of strangers in barely 15 minutes. But both burn the same way. The crematoria may be hard to locate. It's on the right after the main entrance.

A place where to understand Nepal culture . This is where you can review on the subject of Death, which nobody like to talk about when one is alive. But come on, everyday we are just one step closer to death.

Well worth a visit. Visited on an afternoon in a thunderstorm. Number of cremations going on. Fascinating, as a Westerner, to watch the funeral procedures of the Hindu religion. Not ghoulish as you would expect but everybody showed great reverence and respect for the deceased and their families. It's certainly something I will never forget.Disappointing that non Hindus are not allowed into the temple despite being charged NPR1000 ( approx.€8)

Holy Cremation place. the river is considered sacred because it eventually flows into the Ganges River in India, ultimately reaching the holy city of Varanasi. The human body resting on the platform underneath the bright yellow cloth, is burned and the ashes are eventually pushed into the river below, some people found it disturbing especially when you smell the body getting burned.

A Reflecting Moment!. When I went to the Crematoria, I did not know what to expect. First, I saw the smoking pyres, and next, the entire funeral ceremony for a body to be cremated. It was more of a reflecting moment for me, full of spiritual thinking and feeling. This was perhaps the most culturally different of all my experiences in Nepal.

The holiest cremation site in Nepal. The cremation site is at bank of bagmati river at eastern side of Pashupatinath temple. The view of burning bodies made me think the importance of human life. And didn't liked that they threw all remaining in the river(water pollution). I guess new electric cremation site has been built so lets hope pollution is less.

our journey ends here. Pashupatinath is celebrated for its human cremations that take place on the Ghats of the Bagmati River in eastern Kathmandu. The river is considered sacred because it eventually flows into the Ganges River in India, ultimately reaching the holy city of Varanasi.The human body, which is resting on the platform underneath the bright yellow cloth, is burned and the ashes are eventually pushed into the river below.
Old style. Near the airport and install pashupatinath template compound is that cremation palace you are able to see def burning busy

IF DEATH IS YOUR THING. not sure what the attraction is to watch bereaved family members traditionally burning the bodies of their departed on the banks of a dirt river (however holy it may be) and lots of equally dirty saddhus wandering about smoking weed.
Unique site. If you are fascinated with life, living and dying and how others go about it then you must visit this site.
Good. This place is near in pasupatinath Temple you may able to see the cremation Hindu trisection way. You may able to see dead burn body in front in your eyes.
Leave in Peace. I dont the a crematoria is an attraction. Its a place where people depart from their loved ones and so they must be left in peace.

nice. me and my wife been in pashupati nath temal to see shiva temae near temple we been the crematoria this palace is belong to hindus their own traditional to burn ded buddy after ast a away nor to bad palace

Very Interesting.... Seeing the preparations for the cremations, as well as the burning of the bodies was quite an eye-opener. It was an incredible experience, and beautiful in it's own regard. You can stand on the opposite side of the river, or on the bridge.You can also see the Baba's caves, and they are around trying to get you to take photos with them for money. As weird and wonderful as they look, don't fall for it!A must do !!!

Impressive, more beautiful than Varanasi.. When we arrived there were 2 cremations in the make. A bed of orange flowers and cloths were laid out. And then came the deceased. What beautiful rituals and what sadness. It made me almost ashamed to watch.

Interesting place with a view of funerals and cremation. One of the most interesting experiences in Kathmandu. Nice area with temples and monkeys. But the best part is the possibility to witness a hindu funeral with all its particular and beautiful activities and traditions. When there we saw parts of three funerals. And it does not feel like you are intruding as you can sit far away and a lot of locals also hang out and watch "the show".

Largest Hindu Temple. Explore this large Hindu Temple on your own or with a guide. Be prepared to witness a burial (where a body is burned in the Hindu tradition). Monkeys are everywhere, but DO NOT feed them and watch your purse, backpacks and pockets. These little creatures are fast and mischievous!

Once in a lifetime visit. Great experience. Make sure you are respectful as this is the main active cremation site in Kathmandu. Do not feed the monkeys and be careful of taking pictures with those in costume as they will try to charge you heavily afterwards!

The Crematoria was a strange visit to just what one would call "normal sight seeing".. Make sure you understand what you are getting into before going, although I did, it was still hard to fathom. The location is beautiful, and worthy of a National Geographic picture from every angle, however the daily act of cremation here might not be everyone's cup of tea. I think that that says it all...One interesting note, the ashes often are poured into the Bagmati River, right next to those washing their clothes and taking a bathe. Strange combination, but when in Rome...

the smell is beyond discription. I think that it is wonderful to share other cultures and to be part of them. In the west we hide away our dead and in Nepal it is out in the open. I know that different places have different customs and I respect that. I am not very keen on the fact that the refuse of the human burnings go directly into the Bagmati River. Small children wade through the water collecting any and all trinkets from the funerals. I realize that this is a cultural thing, but the pollution bothers me. It is a very holy, very holy site. You can feel the humanity. I will remember this place forever although I am not interested in going back.
Educational. Definitely worth a visit --the ceremonies are caste based and many faceted--surrounding area great--do not miss the hermit enclaves at he far end

Attraction for tourist. This is nothing that attracts a local or Hindu who have seen such cremation many times in life or which is not something attractive, rather that part of ritual that one has to fulfil in their life or be part of it when some nears and dears dies. This is next to the famous temple of Pashupatinath and on the bank of Bagmati river. When a person dies, they are brought here for cremation which is done with fire-woods but know there is also few electrical cremation places which is rather quicker. Many foreigners watches this from the opposite side of the river - though one can also go nearby and see such rituals but mind it that non-hindu are not allowed to enter inside the temple (which is something I am against of and hope it will change one day).

Personal but interesting. I feel awkward taking photos and staring at people during a ceremony, but there were a lot of tourists here and my guide was encouraging photos. It's quite moving to see the spiritual side of this ceremony, to know that there is literally a dead body under the smoke.No, you don't smell anything except maybe sandalwood. Definitely have a guide to explain what you are looking at.

The Crematoria @ Pashumathinath temple. Very eerie and peaceful place to watch the dead on the last journey. The rites performed and the funeral pyre makes one wonder rich our poor , whatever or race we all are one at death

Interesting Place to Visit. You could get good view about the local place and really heart touching. there for ghat just next to the river and give you quite different feeling of spiritual way. Few bucks for the entry. Worth a visit. Should visit if you're in Kathmandu. Enjoy

Way to heaven. Adjacent to the famous Pashupatinath temple is the crematorium , one of the few places where the wooden pyre is still used to complete the last rites. people say its the way to heaven, getting cremated here frees one from the pain of rebirth and attains moksha.

Worth a visit. Although I left before the fire was lit (queasy stomach and all), the visit was interesting. The temple priests were particularly interesting and so were the structures around the crematorium and the stories behind them. I had a good guide who explained all the customs and beliefs about the cremation rituals, and the history of the temple and its inhabitants. Very interesting!

Definitely worth going. Though the visitors are funneled to the opposite side of the river from the ghats you can certainly experience what's happening. It's difficult not to feel intrusive at times. Or that's what I felt anyway.

Visit heaven trek. Im very touching when visited this place last week....when i saw ceremony for cremation, the family go around 3 times and kiss the feet of their parents deceased. Really touching. And worth it to visit, that is my first experience can see the cremation. ;)

Bit morbid, yet, interesting.... It seems quite unusual to visit a cremation site... I had mixed feelings on deciding if I should do it or not. But it does give you a unique view of the local rituals. On my visit there were 3 ceremonies happening at the same time, one of them being of a highly reputed doctor of the region with a big crowd coming to it.
Very interesting. Very interesting place to see a part of Nepalese culture. The site itself is worth a visit and walk around. Entrance fee of NPR1000 or USD$10.
Part of the Pashupatinath complex. The site is the part of the Pashupatinath temple complex, if seeing dead bodies being cremated the Hindu way is your thing then this is the right place for you.

Incredible experience . I've found it hard to describe my feelings about this experience. It's very personal, that's certain. I recommend anyone to visit the Pashupati area and educate the mind on the amazing traditions.

Be prepared to see bodies burning and children playing the river where the ashes are going. This is an interesting place, but also a bit disturbing. I felt like I was a tourist to a moment in life that should have been more intimate. I couldn't bring myself to take pictures of people setting loved ones on fire - you watch the ritual, but it didn't feel right to do so for me. It is definitely a different culture and I brought my bias, so others may find this special rather than uncomfortable. Just be prepared that you are watching actual funerals from across a small river.

Emotional. I was not prepared for the sights we viewed here, and felt like a voyeur on other peoples miseries.I was reassured by our guide that this was not how the locals viewed it but I felt that taking pictures was wrong and disrespectful.

A must see in Kathmandu. I am not one to observe the misfortunes of others, but there were two memorable things about being here. First - it is the presence of true Shiva energy. All through India and Nepal you visit many Shiva temples, but here, in the temples, and especially where the older people live nearby, I felt the most true presence of Shiva. Makes sense, right? And, second; I will always treasure the memory of the evening ceremony that takes place on the banks of the river. It's a time when people gather for music and dance, and thank the Spirits for coming to greet the newly departed loved ones. It's organic, it's real, but, not morbid. This experience was really an honoring of Life, death, and family. It's organic, it's real, but, not morbid.

Special. A bit weird to look at the cremation of a human beings on one side and others (yes, me too) making pictures at the other side. But with a guide we had for 10 dollar it really make sense to go there and learn about the traditions.

I couldn't leave. The reason why I couldn't leave was because of the meaning, philosophy and culture behind this. It was moving and very in your face. The smell and sight drew me to the place and I watched on in fascination...then a wave of sadness smacked me and I was left in a melancholy state for the rest of the day - I couldn't shake the images out of my head and wondered what death means. I said when I was 7 that I wanted to die before my love ones because I can't bear to see them leave....sigh, a moving experience but a sad one

Very moving and fascinating. we saw the cremations in progress, its a little unreal, as it is so different from UK customs, the families and friends all participate and clear the final ashes into the river, en route to the Ganges. sounds a little morbid , but very moving, beware the smell, which can be a little disturbing as it resembles BBQ.

An ethereal experience. Watching from the opposite bank, was a moving experience to observe how Nepalese paid their last respects to a family member. We were mesmerised as senior family members oiled, disrobed the corpse and ignited the funeral plinth, very moving and a privilege to observe. Can't believe some tourists had gone o the other bank, walked upo very closely and started photographing and videoing the ceremony...very disrespectful in my opinion.

Read the reviews before you go!. This is a moving experience, but some may find it disturbing. This is where those who can afford it have their deceased family members cremated on open pyres next to the river. It is a powerful moment, but I wouldn't bring young children or the faint of heart.

Fascinating cultural experience. I would put this towards the top of my list, been here three times, and it is always interesting and I learn a bit more about the traditions and customs of the cremation process every time. I really came away discussed with the American burial and cremation processes. This makes sense to me, and it is definitely not gross in any way.

Very interesting. I was pressured into getting a guide but it was probably worth it because I wouldnt have appreciated what was happening as much. Holy men and women were everywhere but they have highish prices for photos. I felt like a bit of a dick being a tourist here while people are burning their loved ones but it was a special experience. I saw one dead body from a distance but otherwise they were enveloped in fire or covered.

Special experience . It is something really different than in Europe, you see how the bodies are burned and the family and friends of that person. Several traditions (like shaving of all the hairs from the son when the mother or father dies) all happen in public. Just be aware that it could be a bit shocking, however for me it was a peaceful experience.
eye opener. this place is my favourite place, because it really hits home and makes you think about life and the circle of life with your place in it as well

Deep insight into Hindu rituals. Although we turned down numerous offers from tour guides, we managed to find the crematorium to the side of one of the most important Hindu temples in Nepal, possibly the world. Incredibly moving to watch the departed surrounded by friends and family as they are put in place and set alight.
Interesting to be and watch. This is a traditional temple for funerals in the old hindu style. Entrance fee is 1.000 Rps. but worth to spend if you want to watch these rituals.

Old style cremation next to the new option. There are almost always cremations ongoing at this large site, day and night. On the riverside, up to a dozen may take place at once. The newer incinerator is close by and offers a faster, cheaper alternative to those seeking this service, although traditions die hard.Visitors, I.e. Non-Hindus, can view from the gallery across the river. There are also holy men on site who are willing to pose for photographs for a small fee. Not particularly gory, but the squeamish may not enjoy this.
The Crematoria. This was my first visit to a crematoria. The ceremonies were very interesting. I was not able to enter the temple but what I saw looked very impressive.

It is much, much more than just a crematoria......... Pashupatinath temple is the most important temple dedicated to lord Shiva in Nepal and one of its most scared Hindu temples. Located on the banks of the holly Bagmati river (which much further down flows into the Ganges) and at about five km from Kathmandu, Pashupathinath is the place where Hindus from both Nepal and India come to die and be cremated, in the belief that dying in Pashupathinath guarantees their rebirth not as a worm, a pig or a dog, but as human, irrespective of the misdeeds in their lives... You can, of course, observe the bodies being brought to the cremation ghats, the oldest son pouring some incents and holly water from the river before lighting the funeral pyre, then ashes being discarded into the holly Baghmati and further down the river kids playing into the water and women doing their laundry. Here, death is not the end but just another step towards Nirvana.... The temple itself (available only to Hindus) is a masterpiece of Hindu architecture and, if you are interested in religions, in other ways of thinking of life and death, then you may not like to miss a visit Pashupatinath.. .
True confluence of life and death. Should experience from Pashupatinath temple itself unless willing to take a bit of filth. Very clearly visible from temple.
What a site. Once of the most unique things I saw while on my trip to Nepal. We witnessed multiple cremations attended by hundreds of people.

Walk by. The most attraction place for tourist for fooding and night life located at the central of the capital Kathmandu is the best place to hang out. The area touch Indra Chok, Jamal, Lainchour, Dollu, Dalku. My suggestion for the government of Nepal to band the entry of vehicles to Thamel so that the tourist can walk freely and they can shop the soviener.It would be less polluted also and the area would be developed well..

Engaging. This is a strange yet engaging place that seems completely alien to European culture yet means so much to local people. It seems as though there is always a funeral byre ongoing here, sometimes several with the remains being unceremoniously swept into the very murky 'holy' river.

Not something I expected to see with my own eyes. When we visited the Crematoria we certainly didn't expect the cremations to be actually happening...though we probably should of! It was not a sad place even with what was happening. When we visited there were six cremations happening along the river......people were casually viewing over lunch or just sitting quietly and watching. One thing to be aware of is unfortunately the smell but dont let that turn you off visiting such a culturally rich place....use a head scarf over your nose as that will get you through. It costs 500NPR per person.

Religion of Hindu. when i visited Kathmandu i went to Hindu Crematoria place thats called lord Shiva pashupatinath temple. this is situated Bagmati river it is a huge temple in the world of Hindu religion.it is very old temple and built by wood handicraft statue of many gods.i like that temple to visit in Kathmandu Nepal. so, if you want plan to visit Kathmandu don't miss to visit that place. thanks..

Rich of Historic value. . This is the biggest Crematoria in Kathmandu and has lots of temples surrounding. This is the place dedicated to the birth of life and death. One side is used for the purification of the bodies and across the bridge is the burning or cleansing of the bodies. Men are placed west to east and women are east to west. If you have a weak stomach be prepared to see actual bodies being burnt. When i went there was 2 already burning and 3 booked so I was able to see the whole process. They are monkeys here so keep your bag with you and if you want to take a picture with the holy men they expect a tip of about 250 ruprees each which I though was ridiculous but a tip or donation is not required but they will get upset if you don't tip them. One the far side you can see houses in the mountain where the priests live both Hindu and buddest are burnt here. The white temple you aren't allowed to enter this is where the holy water that purifies the body comes from and is prohibited for foreigners to enter but can see from the rop of the hill in full view. Definitely worth a trip to see and the entry cost is 1000 ruprees for two temples the other temple is about a 25 min walk from the starting point. The building survived the earthquake quite good with only afew small temples beyond repair.
Interesting and powerful. To fully understand this site please hire a guide it was work his salary times two!!! This site is a holy place with the river and the rituals that take place.

Never seen anything like it.... Wow, this was new experience for me, public cremations, and the stench of the river...for a soft westerner pretty like me mind blowing...certainly a experience one should see and smell...suggest you take a mask....

Hindu culture to the max. When in Kathmandu you must come here.
The epicenter of Hindu culture. Its a surreal experience to be walking up one side of the river and photographing someone being cremated on the other.
fascinating but sad. We were taken here by our guide, it was something that we'd only ever seen on TV before. It was indeed fascinating but sad to see.

Eye opening visit.. Surprised this is open to tourists- it was quite jarring to see the cremations. While interesting, it seems like it should be reserved only to family's in mourning or for religious purposes.

Visit May 2016. Very interesting and fascinating - bodies being cremated on the river bank on open fires (similar to Varanasi in India I believe). Also attended the Aarti ceremony which is performed nightly by a selected family - really nice to be up close and personal for such a ceremony

An ancient and timeless ritual. Located at the Pashupatinath Temple in Kathmandu the creamatorum has remained busy since the 2015 earthquake . An important part of Hindu life the funeral fires burn all day and all night.
This is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Part of the adjacent temple complex.. An opportunity to view a different approach to death. Not for the squeamish. You will see dead bodies.

A must see. This was my 3rd time there and even so the earthquake has destroyed some of the temple, it was a great experience. This place is very peaceful and the atmosphere is very serene and beautiful. Our guide Subash (+9779851185516) was great.

Absolute must do. It is a little over whelming when you first arrive if you are not from a culture that celebrates life/ death in this way. I loved understanding more of the Hindu culture and this sacred place. A very unique experience

Authentic experience. Even though you'll be hard-pressed to avoid the "guides", our visit included monkeys, bodies being prepared for cremation, bodies in the process of being burned, and even a bull (with very big horns) wandering the streets.

Make sure you stay for a whole ceremony. If you have not seen the Hindu ritual of death and cremation then stop and watch from the moment someone if brought here, to how they are cleaned to moving them to other side of River to how cremation is set up to the actual lighting of the flames. Quieting.

Moving but not for the fainthearted. You see actual cremations here so be prepared to acknowledge and respect that. Go with a guide so you can understand the significance and history of the place. Sad to see the river so polluted. Pay the holy men a couple dollars & get a picture of a lifetime with them!
Cultural education. An absolutely intreaging insight into Hindu customs and ceremonies. It was a real privilege to witness

very unique experience of passing and celebration. It's not a normal day out, but to see a beautiful and open celebration of life and death is a cultural must do. Be prepared to pay to come in if you are foreign. At night, there is a cool ceremony just after dusk. Really a beautiful way to celebrate life.

Fire. In hindu traditisnal when people past the away thad ded buddy can fire in open place in frent of people their own traditional same people like sam people don,t like about my vision must sev the tradinationnal

Mini Varanasi at a Powerful Place. First thing, this shouldn't showed as a separate view point as this is comes under Holy Pushipatinah temple.I'm not the person who visit crematoria place, etc or it just wasn't my thing, but was so curious to see what exactly happening here after heard about this place in blogs and travel forums and via SM. When i was at this place there were two cremations taking place at the same time and it shows how Hindu rituals taken place after a death. with all the rituals it actually a 3-4 hours process. so i couldn't stay that long and walked away after few minutes. It reminds Varanasi (but here they don't put the body in river). After all, I wouldn't say it's a must see in Pushipatinah temple (temple is a must visit place) but if you are so curious about Hindu cremation, rituals, etc a must visit at your own risk.Mini Varanasi at a Powerful Place
extraordinary. worth visiting for understanding the boundaries between life and death and for understanding hindu culture. Keep face masks with you

A must see in Katmandu. If you only visit one or two places in Kat make sure this is one. Tourist tickets are 1000 rupees and a guide will ask for a matching amount but then settle for 600. It's a good way to give back and get a few insights that might otherwise have been missed. 30 minutes is plenty of time to see the area and you can stay longer to quietly watch the cremations from the visitor area across the river.They were performing a few cremations while I was there and I didn't experience the horrible smells or recoil in horror at the idea of bodies burning. It is a ceremony to move the Hindu deceased on to their next life. Yes there are people grieving and crying but ten minutes after the cremation starts everyone leaves and has had their closure. There are the tourists with the large lenses snapping away... yes annoying but it is 50 yards from the pyres and a given constant backdrop to the cremation ceremony. I snapped a few pictures and that was enough. There are millions of better pictures available... no need for more. Take a few minutes to sit and just be silent during the ceremony. Some people feel a great connection. I just think it is a very peaceful way to say goodbye in my eyes. No invasive embalming and viewings and caskets... just $10000 rupees and ashes to ashes.

Grizzly, but engaging too. It's an unusual place to visit. Bodies are usually cremated early in the morning before tourists with cameras descend on the place. You will see piles of ashes, smouldering pyres and wood ready for the next body. You will also be pestered by fake gurus and watch out for the monkeys!
A must . Visit in Kathmandu. A glimpse into how the Hindus say goodbye to the dead. Great photo opportunities if done discretely.

A Sobering look at Hindu Culture - A Must See if you enjoy Authenticity !. This is absolutely a must see, although i can't help but thing that it is clearly dark tourism, and felt guilty all the way through watching a cremation. Most visitors will not realize that it is a working facility, and when we visited a cremation had just begun. The family were not concerned the slightest about anyone watching and being able to witness the deeply personal display of cultural grief is something I won't forget.

Very special . Besides the ceremonie there are a lot of beautiful temples surrounding it. Sadly there has been some damage due to the earthquake of 2015 but still very beautiful. Sadly I wasn't able to witness a ceremony so I advise to check with your hotel or guide to see when a ceremony will be.
Experience the Hindu cremation ritual. Cremations take place next to the Bagmati River on the grounds of the Pashupatinath Temple. There are many cremation ceremonies every day.

Flaming cremations. There were three cremations going on when we were there. Next to the fires were buckets of ghee (clarified butter) which is the fuel for the cremation. There are many wild monkeys in the area.

A unique and terrifying experience. If you can handle the smell and sight of dead bodies, then go for it, otherwise, you'd better do something else instead. I wouldn't say it's a must see in Kathmandu but if you are curious about Hindu cremation, visit at your own risk.

Moving. I was very surprised by how moving this place is. It is more moving than I thought it would be even though knowingly it is a place for mourning before visiting. Came here before sunset to see families mourn for their loved ones. Must see and be sure to give yourself plenty of time to just sit and observe. Try not to take a lot of photos out of respect for the families.

This is the same as the Pashupatinath Temple. Don't know why this is showed as a separate item as this is the same as the Pushipatinah temple. A must see if in Kathmandu as it is the most important Hindu temple in Kathmandu. Not for the faint of heart as it is a cremation place.

Fascinating, but strange viewing. We visited because we were in the area and thought it would be interesting, but it felt very strange watching people grieve and not knowing the people concerned. We didn't stay too long. The process of preparing the body by the family is very respectful and interesting to see, but it just wasn't my thing. There are market stalls outside selling jewellery, brass ornaments and the usual stuff too, so we enjoyed the walk around afterwards.

Unique experience at the Pashupatinath Temple area. Not for children or gawking tourists with cameras. This is a solemn place along the Bagmati River on the grounds of the Pashupatinath Temple. You will likely see a cremation ceremony, especially earlier in the morning. It is a religious ceremony and one should be respectful. There are buildings and small structures that you can take pictures of on the grounds. Avoid the monkeys, and if you want to take pictures of the 'holy men, they will expect a small tip.

Behind the Pashupathinath Temple- on river bank of Bhagmathi River- Funeral rituals as Hindhu customs. Most impressive , beautiful scene of funeral rites, on the bank of river Bhagmathi. It looked as if its a celebration - of funeral pyre of several mortal remains of people of Kathmandu.
Confronting but fascinating. This was confronting for many in our group but also fascinating. The fact that it is a working crematorium adds to the fascination.

Interesting but weird. I still don't know how to feel about this place, it interesting but is a crematorium. If you look past the weirdness, it good to help you understand the Hindu culture and part of the city that is Katmandu
Unique Experience. Well, that was a unique experience as Americans are not accustomed to this. Probably not for the squeamish or young children.

Very special Place but not for every one. This place is very unique but if you sensitive for the smells- I don't recommend it.
The surrounding area is very dirty and filthy . It is special site but must prepare your soul to the view when hang around the burning platform . It is not an ordinary place to see.
Cultural Diversity. Seems like a ghoulish place to visit but the Hindu end of life rituals are very public and it's fascinating to watch and quite peaceful.
Smoke.... When they told us we will visit this place i was not sure i want to go there. But in the and i can say it is worthwhile.

Expensive, but well worth seeing. 1000 rupees for foreigners, but you have to make a special effort to walk into the booth to pay. I would suggest just trying to walk down the street, I don't think you'd be stopped. Really interesting to see. All the rituals involved in the cremations, which are constant. May not be for the faint hearted, as the cremations nearest the temple you can see dead people's faces.
Goos experience. Great experience to see that traditional habit. Something else from what we know and see. Must visit but on the other hand a bit difficult to watch that ceremony.

Interesting place to visit. Very interesting place to visit especially if you have a guide to explain everything you see. This is a Hindu area with plenty of souvenir stalls selling all sorts of Nepali things.

Loved this place . Entry fees was 1000 rs , you can see how the Hindu religion deal with the dead body after death ,Evening times you can see the dead bodies , u can take pictures , there is a lot of future tellers , hand reader etc. u can buy some nickels hand made , then u can access the main tample you are not allowed to use the camera but it's a nice place to have a look and see other cultures. 5/5

Expensive tourist trap. The Crematoria is meant to be a very humbling spiritual place, however we felt it was being ruined by the hawkers. Foreigners have to pay 1000Rs to enter, and while it was interesting to see the culture and you can see funerals taking place (which is very interesting) there are many "holy" men trying to get you to take photos in exchange for money/vendors hassling you to purchase things.
It was an interesting cultural experience. It is worth seeing, but I'm not sure I would do it again. It is fascinating to see how they prepare the bodies for cremation.

weird place, strange experience but truely mesmerising and divine.. went with my partner and his friend. I was told its a temple and it was. but did not expect to have the first hand experience of seeing the cremation and it was done in the open air. the evening prayer however was very divine and relaxing. the view from the terrace facing the main temple is phenomenal.

An amazing place to visit. It seems to be OK to observe a cremation ceremony, be respectful and don't be like a crazy tourist taking lots of photos up close. I met a local guide he took me to the river side cremations and explained the temple. It can be an emotional visit, I saw a whole family say good bye to their mother, the smell of smoke and the crowds of visitors, it was a day I wont forget.
An intrusion?. This place is quite and so interesting, but when there is a funeral going on it feels as if the world is intruding on someone else s grief.

Strangely Beautiful…. Getting to see and experience the traditional Hindu cremation was quite an experience. It was "strange" because it is not something that I am accustomed too, but beautiful, because it is a centuries old tradition.

Great cultural experience. Got to go to view this site and experience a creamation via our tour company we booked with. So different how they deal with their death and preparations of the deceased. Reading about different cultures is good but, being there in person is somethings different altogether.

A Hindi ceremony.. It costs 1000 NPR to enter. AU$12. The area is quite large. As you walk along the path, you see the cement squares with wood on top. When I was there there was a ceremony for the deceased. It can be quite unsettling, but you have to remember that this is their custom. On one side of the bridge was quite an elaborate ceremony and on the other very basic. There was a total of 5 when I was there. Be aware that you do see the feet and face of the deceased and you do see the fires being lit. Once they do light, the body is covered with wet straw, so there is smoke.

The rule of life. I've visited this place several times but the place hasn't been empty once. If you're a scary person or dead bodies disgusts you, I suggest you not to go. However, watching the corpses burn and learning the truth of life was an interesting experience for me.

Creepy Place. The Crematoria is where the Hindus burn the bodies. When I was there, I witness bodies burning in front of my eyes; very creepy and morbid. This place is definitely not for family with kids. The only highlight of this place is the colorful persons hanging around the temple.Expect to paid Rs1000 or +/-$10.00 for entry.
A little weird for Western culture. Worth a visit as it is interesting to witness different cultures. The actual place is nice and it is worth a look around if you are in the area.

Worth the visit. If you have never seen anything like this before, it is well worth the visit to see this interesting cultural custom.
Bring a mask as the air is quite polluted with smoke in the area.

A bit weird but a must see. For European standards it is a bit weird to see the Nepalese's burning their dead bodies on the river but also a very interesting experience. There was a bridge over the river which the children used for taking a jump in the river which made the whole scenario a bit unreal but i guess it could be considered as the circle of life. The atmosphere offers both from sad to happy feelings.

Seems a little invasive.. Although the experience is interesting one has to wonder if invading the cremation of people's relatives is a little macabre. You will probably see a "sadu" or two around. I was told by the guide that these are not real ones but just men trying to earn a few rupees by posing for photos.

Quite an eye-opening experience. Our group happened upon a guide (he was selling items and since it wasn't busy, he started telling us what was happening at the riverside) and it really helped explain the procedure. I'm glad that I saw this part of Nepalese culture and I would certainly suggest it to other people. However, it is important to know what you are going to see - and be prepared for it. After saying that, there is much, much more to look at if you choose to 'miss' this area and enjoy the the temples and beauty in the area.

Visiting this attraction is a very personal choice. I happened on this site purely by accident.Perhaps a guide would have given me an in depth history and rationale of this Hindu funeral ceremony.Without this historical and religious information I was left with a bit bewildered.
This is a part of the Hindu culture.. Listening to a guide reveal the reasons for the funeral fires answers questions I didn 't know how to ask.

So Fascinating, But Strange At the Same Time!. This was so bizarre! You can sit and watch grieving families cremate their dead loved ones, which sounds quite sick, but it provides a fascinating insight into Nepalese culture and rituals.You can see the workers building the log platforms, washing the straw (to make it pure) then you see the family doing the final preparations on the body before it's set alight. Bizarre, but fascinating!On a side note, we weren't bothered by many beggars or hawkers here.

Impressive Hindu cememony. Watch the family of a recent decedent bring the body down to the river to be cleansed. Typically, the head and feet are washed by the oldest son (or oldest male relative), then the body is taken over to the crematoria. There, the body is wrapped in wood, lit on fire, and burned for approximately three hours. Afterwards, the ashes are shoveled up and tossed into the river.

Great. I was told i could go anywhere so I did (except the temple, oh and the army bit) I went and watched a few baby funerals and then a few full size adults,because I'm interested in that and it was fascinating, very.I ended up with a front row seat in fact, at one point all the mourners (there's not actually much mourning going on except by perhaps the main relative) moved themselves around me accidentally whilst they talked business as they moved away from the burning body I was completely in the middle of them all, nobody minded in the slightest.If you're not sure of how to behave at a funeral then i wouldn't recommend going in close but if you have some genuine compassion then go take look.I wonder if people on the other side of the river don't pay if they arrive from that side.

Fasanting. Such a weird place to be as a westerner, seeing the sad family saying goodbye to there loved ones. Not for the faint hearted.
Lots of wild life.

Interesting to know. I was curious about this place and my local nepali friend explained to me about the history, their culture & the lifestyle of people in nepal..my tip advice: bring small guide book with u, it will be useful to learn more
Truly interesting. It was just so amazing to see what the people on nepal do with their their relatives. A must see. Just so surreal

Dark. I was excited to get to know the place, had heard many stories and knew that would be incredible to see it. Got to know some Nada Saghu Hindu Holyman and be involved, get knowledge about different faiths and beliefs, but while I was there I felt sad, watch the ceremonies that happen there is sad. There was this dark energy around, there was too much fog in the air, especially when I visited (beginning of the year), there had been a lot of rain, the sky was dark, winds were strong, the water in the river is dark, its color is totally black and it just reminded me death.

Good with a guide. We went there and my wife was exception some wonderful temple to see. Unfortunately the pretty temple is not allowed for foreigners. The crematory part is interesting, there is quite a lot to know about it but you need a guide (or may be a travel book would do it?).We paid 500 ruppies and got 1H tour.
do not miss this. I was not prepared to stumble on this...there were 3 cremations on the go. Fascinating and quite civilized. Would be a great way to disappear someone.

Pasupatinath, is worshipped by Hindus all around the world.Hindus believed once life must visit for purity of spirit.. The Crematoria plate interesting story. Nepali Hindus believe, this body to be made of five elements (earth,water,fire,air and sky) However by burning the dead body they believe to send back the respective elements to theirs sources earth-ash,fire-heat, air-smoke,water-water and sky-soul these goes to nature.

One the great Kathmandu experiences. I have been here numerous times. Standing in front of a temple to the Karma Sutra you can look right, though an archway, where bodies are being cremated. The intricate ceremony, preparation of the body gives a telling insight into belief. Death as part of life. It can be a puzzling place, intense and deeply cultural. A guide is a good idea. Take a walk over the bridge and up the steps and walk towards the space where you can sit and look out over the whole remarkable site. Worth also visiting the ashram, and the adjacent old people's home. Non Hindus can see into the temple to Lord Shiva by leaving the site. On the left as you walk towards the entrance is a small room where there are physical representations of the first Hindus. Overall is not a disturbing place, although some find it so. More it is a place of contemplation and wonder.

Cultural experience. Went to the crematoria as part of a tour and didn't actually realise we were going there until we were there. The tour guide was fair blasé about the bodies being cremated and the funeral in progress while we were there. It's part of life there and it's good not to hide away from the realities of life when you're in a different country/culture.
A Must See In Kathmandu. A experience that touches all of your senses. Something you will never forget. No more than an hour is plenty of time to spend.

Different Feel from Varanasi. Viewed a cleansing of an older man and preparation for cremation. The people are open to outside viewing which provided an excellent education about the rituals. Very moving!

Cultural experience. Observing how Hindu people are performing their ancient rituals and sending farewells to their loved ones-unforgettable. I was observing quietly and did not want to impose. I have mixed feelings of other 'tourists' taking pictures of the dead ones as they were some kind of tourist attraction...

A fascinating glimpse. This was a really great opportunity to see a Hindu ceremony in process while maintaining a respectful distance. The guide we had was able to explain everything and enhanced the experience.

A wonderful sight ruined by being over run with sadus, beggars and hawkers. I have been here before many years ago and then it was a surreal, mystical place, where, being a tourist meant showing respect for those creating their dead and sharing the wonder of the temples so I was very disappointed to find, today it is now a crazy tourist trap where, although those saying goodbye to their loved ones are still there, anyone choosing to visit is likely to be hassled to the point of craziness for money, to buy tat or to have a "blessing" from a sadu for cash.I lasted about an hour and then I had had enough. The taxi driver on the way back explained that these sadus are not real ( they are simply Indian people who have come here to dress up as a form of begging) and that nearly all the people selling stuff and begging are Indian too. I must say, I have never come across Nepali people as pushy or intimidating at all, so I have no reason not to believe this is the case. Tourists beware - it is an amazing place but to be avoided if you don't want a constant stream of " in your face" begging. What a shame as it is supposed to be holy place and for the local Nepali people who are there to grieve it must be a horrible thing to have to witness.

Sad reminder of the cycle of life at Pashupatinath complex. An interesting but sad reminder of our inevitable destiny. Although worth seeing, may not be for the faint-hearted although our teenager had no problem. Walking amongst the grieving families was not pleasant. One just needs to give them some privacy.
Where the pyre burns. On the banks of the river, there is a certain chill and also calmness. You see hindu dead bodies being cremated to ashes. Very photogenic place and also surreal.

Facinating open air creamatory. Never in my life did I expect to see bodies of the deceased put on stretchers over a roaring fire and burnt until the body disintegrated in flames, but that is exactly what I saw at the Crematoria in Kathmandu. Very interesting to see how the fire is built and straw is washed before adding it to the fire so as to be pure. The cremation that happens before the eyes of loved ones. The final honor; the final exit. You can't help but be affected by the ceremony, next to the river, out in the open. So in tune with how we live our lives.
Historical Place to visit when you are in Nepal. Definitely a excited historical place in Kathmandu and one must see its history. Excellent for photography.
A very interesting insight into the local culture. It was fascinating to watch the funeral ceremony and the cremation process and to see the different ways different cultures deal with grief.
Fascinating. An insight into the Nepalese culture and the ceremony around death. Quite a lot to look at around the complex.

Cultural site, but foreigners are out of place. The reason I travel is to see how other people live. I enjoy experiencing the culture, the food, and the people. Even though The Cremotoria is a place where the dead are put to rest, I thought it would be beautiful to see how the Nepalese say goodbye to their lost loves, see what kind of rituals they have, and to witness their views on death but I didn't feel peace when I was there. Watching families cry in pain on the river bank, watching their deceased burn, in the open public felt wrong. It felt as if we were invaded a sacred private moment, the last moment people have to their mothers, fathers, sisters, brothers, cousins, and friends. There is little steps set out into the river bank and there burning stations about every 20 feet, so cremations are going on right next to one another. Aside from the act of the cremations, there is beggars, homeless, hustlers, and creeps.. Everywhere! Every step you take theirs either someone trying to relentlessly sell you something, peeing in public, following you for money, or sleeping on the floor next to you. It felt invasive in the first place to be at funerals uninvited, but the loitering crowd that hangs out around there made us feel uncomfortable, unsafe, and unsettled. If you see pictures of this place I feel like that would be enough for you. But if you really must go experience this for yourself, just be on guard.

A solemn and mystical place. We were dropped off here to spend an hour by our driver. We wer approached by a young man who offered his services as a guide. He stated that we could pay him any price depending on his level of service. Now this is not an authorised guide as you get at some locations. He was not only informative but very friendly. He took us places we would not have known about and explained the ceremony and all the buildings in the area and their significance. A little history on the Hindu religion so we could understand some of their ceremonies and figures.I was going to turn him away but I am so glad we did not. Turned out to be a very interesting time in a special place

Deeply moving way to say farewell to your loved ones. This crematorium is a very open affair. You can see the grief and the sombre nature of the whole process as the deceased is prepared and then burnt.

Something different to experience if you haven't before. This place shows how life and death are integrated into everyday living. It's something different if you haven't experienced anything like this before, but some people may find it disturbing as the bodies are carried to the fire. It is a very natural place.

Good experience . One of good experience to see Nepalis do cremation of the dead bodies. The tradition and religion of the locals, the river where they throw the stuff after procession, stupas after the bridge and walk through garden till the end of the site. Lots of stairs and hilly path. Big area to see by walking. We took taxi to reach this place. Worth to visit in Kathmandu.
unerals. on the day that we visited there were 5 funerals.....taking place unlike India you can take photos across the river.....found it a moving experience

Place of Reflection and Cultural Fascination. Like my review of the Pashupatinah Temple, I saw this first on National Geographic's "Taboo". The crematorium is a religious area so forgive the smell of cinders and burning sulfur (human remains). Bring a good guide to explain the fundamental details such as what the Bagmati river represents, what the cremation intends to fulfill and the like. Days prior my visit my friend died so this tour offered me the PERFECT opportunity to pray for her soul. I asked a Holy Man to perform the Shradh Ceremony on me on her behalf and we did it at the foot of the river. It was an enlightening, emotional experience. Since the water is polluted with burned human remains it's a biohazard so I had to clean myself up a lot when I got to the hotel but the experience was worth it and I hope the ceremony has served its purpose and brought my friend safely to the afterlife.

To remember the dead. It's a religious place to visit. You cans see dead people burning ( cremation). For me to go to this place, make me remember we will dead as human being, so before we die make our life useful.

Very special place where hindu people cremate their family. For just a minor fee you get acces to an attraction not seen in the Western world. 24 hours a day, hindu families cremate their deadline love ones on the river bank. Theres constantly a lot activity going on, bringens dead people in and arranging new wood fires for the cremation.The fire has to be started by the oldest son or if no son, the oldest male relative. This person has to shave his hair of and dress in White and touch the river with his feets.You are able to watch the scenary as long as you like, from the riverbank opposite to the cremation area. The Big hindu temple only allows access for hindu people.Great place to visit and absolutely a must see in KTM.

Shocking then get to used it.... When ypu see the first time , the smell and view are really shocking and you think it is not real. But after a while, you see people how they have belief and praying , you feel difference. İt is really interesting experience but i strongly recommend you to see different side of nature and humanity...

Smokey, dirty,and kinda sad. Watching folks bringing their loved one and then walking the ritual surrounding a cremation was interesting but it was sad to see so many dead bodies being brought for cremation. It was also sad to see that the dead were burning out in the open each having their own bonfire. Having a mask helped with the smoke and air pollution.

Full cultural experience.. Our guide took us to this place as part of the tour. We took baby steps going in. But after the initial emotional response, settled in to watch this ancient ceremony sending the dead to their new beginnings. We become a spectator, showing respect by not talking very much or taking too many photos. Colorful Brahman priests were present. Monkeys were also in attendance. The dead are covered in ceremonial garments and adornments. Logs cover the body while being cremated. There are no views that should disturb anyone who might be sensitive. The feet were visible, during the bathing process, which bothered my friend. The river, where the ashes are sent, was naturally polluted. The man with no legs lying in the road as we left, begging, was more eye opening than the cremations. A visit will add more to the Hindu experience than food or monuments.

Odd experience. We walked there from Thamel and got to see some local living, which was nice. The place itself was a little confusing. There were multiple areas we weren't allowed to go as we were not Hindu. These were not always clearly marked so we always felt like we were trespassing. There were a lot of people hanging out there and some of them were fairly disrespectful to the temples and visitors. Other than the crematorium area there are some buildings to look at when you walk around. Not sure if it was worth the money but I guess an interesting cultural experience.
Hindu tradition. This was very interesting as our guide was Hindu. He explained the responsibilities of the family during this time and we witnessed the whole process

open crematory !!. next side of main pashupati temple , this crematory situated. most of the hindu people of Kathmandu would like to be cremated when they die. result of this crematory is pollution in the river Bagmati.

A must to view Hinduism: temple and the crematoria. Outside of India, the temple and the crematoria is one of the oldest religious sites in Nepal. As long as you are respectful, viewing the cremation is not a problem,. Be sure to walk to the front of the temple on the side of the river. To see the Golden Bull, go the left of the temple.

Interesting insight into Nepalese culture. Definitely worth the entry price, and to get a guide to talk you through the tour was great as I was told many things about the history and goings-on that I would otherwise have no idea about. An eye-opening eperience to see beggers sifting through human ashes while fresh bodies are prepared for cremation.

Surreal, somber experience.... We spent several hours strolling Pashupatinath. The Crematoria was a huge skew to our cultural norms. We couldn't believe what we were watching. It felt a bit awkward being voyuers to all this grieving, but at the same time, perhaps comforting to to the mourners. There were many pyres being prepared and many funerals in progress. Go see this. Be careful to be respectful.
Interesting. It was interesting to observe the ceremony. not for the faint hearted as you do see things and nothing is hidden

high spirits place. a very emotional place , where you feel surrounded by life and death at the ame time, in a simple , spiritual and emotional way. Mourners carrying bodies and visitors watching, sâdhus waiting to see tourists and monkeys playing with ashes in the river.

The cremation site. It is a part of Nepalese culture. It is worth visiting. I felt uneasy though, because there were cremation rituals taking place when I was there.Besides, there were lots of locals spending their time there just sitting and watching
A must see to understand culture. Although not typical for a tour, visiting this crematoria with a knowledgeable guide certainly adds character to a cultural experience.

Hindu temple, Buddhist Shrine and Cremation site. It is hard to review such a place as excellent. It is first and foremost a place of mourning. The cremation site is used by both Hindus and Buddhists and it is a very sobering sight.The temple complex is large and walking around you can meet Sadhus who do not speak but are happy to pose for you for a few dollars. Buddhist sages have also lived there in the past in a series of small caves along the river. In front of the river, there is also a hospice where dying people are cared for.This is not the sanitized western version of death but it is a very human one. All in all, for me, it is a magical place but it may not be for everyone. When I left Kathmandu last April a few days after the earthquake, my last image was the burning pyres of Pashupatinah. This is why I am going back this fall and will visit this place again.

A quick but interesting visit. A very sombre place but when explained is much more spiritual than it would first appear. Lots of smoke but doesn't smell as bad as you would think. An enlightening place

It's a solemn place.. A person, possibly a priest, was preparing a pyre while I was there, complete with festoons of yellow flowers, with straw and wood under a canopy. Then he lit it and helped it spread. Later he stoked it with a bamboo pole. There are a number of onlookers, probably family, but also some curious. It's a solemn place.

place to think about life. that's real crematorium, you can see died bodies and how they are burning, to feel this smell. I had feeling of dyrtiness all the time and after visit had feeling that all dress soak up the smell of burned bodies. Atmosphere is like in any crematorium with additions of dogs and monkeys running along burning bodies.

Fascinating cultural site. Personally, it was a bit overwhelming to see the whole process so close. There were a few families occupying burning sites, and others that allowed the dead's feet to be submerged in water (so that their souls can travel with the river) before the procedures took place.
Fascinating. Very intriguing visit to see live funerals happening right in front of you. Our guide took us through the ins and outs of what happens and why etc etc.

Best seen from behind pashupati temple. Although non Hindus are excluded from entering the actual temple, we are able to climb the hill from behind the temple to view the ghats as well as the beautiful pashupati pagoda temple. It is peaceful and a bathroom is available for the public.

patshupatinath. Try to visit this place very early morning time, you discover the real life to nepali people and in this early time, not so much tourists,you stay from 6 am to 11 am or more, so many things to see this place is almost the more old place from kathmandu valley

The Burning Ghats at Pashupati Temple. Personally, I have never understood the interest of the casual tourist in the burning ghats at Pashupati Temple complex. The practice of standing across the river from the ghats and photographing the funerals, for that is what the cremations really are, with long distance lenses, I find abhorrent. Would we want people from a foreign country witnessing our grief at the loss of a loved one? These are private moments and should not be used for personal titillation.

Worth the trip. Extremely interesting excursion - I would recommend enlisting the services of a local guide (we were able to find someone at the entrance). They often work for tips, so plan accordingly.I was impressed at how many areas were open to the public - it's quite an incredible place and not one to be missed!

An interesting area to visit. The crematoria is at the bottom of Monkey temple and is definitely worth the visit. Despite the sad circumstances (you will see cremations occurring) it is an interesting place to visit and learn about the Hindu faith and what families do and how they cope during death of a loved one. You will see and hear families mourning, see cremations happening, see the young boys who work there. It is not as gruesome as it sounds! And the Monkey temple that it is a part of is beautiful too.

Interesting for people of all ages. Went here with our three children, and we all came away moved by the experience. It was fascinating, and yet hard to watch at the same time. We did have a hard time breathing the air there - the smoke was pretty thick in some areas and made a few of us feel sick.
Buddhist and Hindu rcremation. A fascinating glimpse of the rituals and traditions which accompany a cremation in Nepal- with the open air ceremony very different to what is experienced in the West

Fascinating place.. I spent a fair amount of time with Bishnu and Kunjan (staff at Hotel Thamel). Three cremations were in progress when I was there, and we saw several more funeral processions during the day. Recommended for the culturally minded. Perhaps too disturbing for small children. But it is an important aspect of Nepalese life. Fascinating, truly.

Very interesting. My son and I are always up for something a bit off the beaten path.Cost was 1000. Guides are extra. Of course you don't hire them they just hang out with you and talk and talk. Eventually, they say if you're satisfied you can give some tips. But the price is up to you...sort of. Our guy was ok, but not special...he wanted $40US for a "tip". He didn't get it and was quite offended...Still, having a guide is helpful to explain what you're seeing. There are frequent cremations so you'll almost certainly see one. It is quite dis inverting to realize how fresh the grief is that you're seeing...usually the death is less than 24hrs earlier. Still, they charge a fee to enter so you're free to watch and photograph.Most of the hermits which want you to take their ok tyre are fakes...but their dope is not! The real hermits are hidden away, but your guide will show you if you wish. The real ones ignore you and don't care if you take their picture.Our taxi waited for us, cor this service he wanted 200 even though we didn't ask. He didn't get it either. The main road is only ~1km walk so taxis are easy to get.
Definitely worth it. Definitely worth a visit to see this rich cultures way of celebrating death, be careful of the monkeys they are not very friendly!
Morbid fascination. Its just interesting to see how othere cultures deal with death. This is all out there in the open andbeing dealt with

Macabre yet interesting. This was en eye opener into Nepalese culture with several pyers burning bodies upon our visit. It felt invasive being able to witness a family's grieving so openly for all to see but was interesting to gain some insight into Nepalese funeral culture.

An unforgettable experience. This is the first time I saw the cremation ceremony in Hindu traditions. I believed that I had to visit India for the experience, but I could finally get to it in Nepal. There were English speaking guide, whom would approach you when he identified you were tourists, and actively provide service of explaining the tradition of all kind of ceremonies. And this is not included in the ticket.

Very special.... This is where you enter right into the hindu funeral ceremony, their beloved ones are decorated and after that placed on a pile of wood to be burned and ashes thrown into the (somewhat dirty) river below. Lots of monkees jumping around all over the place. It feels kinda "strange" to be a spectator.

Exploring Mortality. visiting the cremation ghats at Bagmati river close to Pashupathinath temple is an opportunity to reflect on death, dying and mortality. There is also a hospice close to ( actually opens to) the crematoria, were people come to die in the terminal phase of their life
Fascinating. The ceremonial crematoria is a fascinating look at the Hindu culture. A guide helps explain the nuances of what is happening and how the castes are treated.

Go beyond checking the box. How a society handles the dead is an integral part of how it lives. Tourists thrust into the crematoria to see how the Hindus dispose mortal remains can make this experience a bit jarring - if you are not accepting of death and live in denial, this may not be the place for you. Picture being taken to cemetries of any other faith and you will see that it is the same experience that you would get. For non-Hindus, this is the closest you get to Pasupatinath Temple. Spend some time contemplating on death and the inevitability of it in human life.

Be Ready For This. My wife and I visited during our 25th Anniversary Tour of India and Nepal. Whilst it seems a strange place to visit we wanted to experience all what this culture has to offer. On entering the facility we were filled with apprehension. However after a short time, and the senerity and calmness of everybody we really started to understand. We saw many families saying goodbye to their loved ones by firstly washing the deceased face, then moving them to the cremation. No outpouring of grief was experienced just a calm and loving goodbye. a very dignified ending. Take some time to meet with the 'holy men' in their 'temples' opposite and have great photos taken . We left feeling relaxed about what we had seen. But I guess not for everybody, but dont be concerned about visiting...

After Death Process !!!. Mind Blowing and Thrilling !!!My Spiritual yatra to Mount Kailash was turned in to 10days tour to Nepal from 24.09.15 to 02.10.15 due to non availability of permit from Chinese government, I went to this thrilling crematoria on 25th September 2015 after have Blissful Darshan of Shree Pasupathinath ji, this place is adjacent to Pasupathinath temple and on the banks of Bagmathi river, 11 dead bodies where burning on that day, it was a mind blowing activity.Must visit for all age groups when we are in Kathmandu, please experience this experience for the experience sake.Thanks a lot for everything,Loving you so much,Peacefully yours,S M Bega Raaj.Happy travelling...

Fascinating !!. It was very strange and a bit disturbing seeing the Crematoria. A bit disturbing in that it seems a huge invasion of privacy for the families who have lost love ones , but a fascinating insight into the Hindu culture !!

Interesting to watch. The crematorium is an interesting area. You will see families mourning their family member and then carrying them over to the area to be cremated. They put them on one of the cement slabs by the water, where there can be people in the water fishing for coins that have been thrown in, and they cover them with stalks and start burning them. Afterwards they spread the ashes into the water. It was quite somber, and interesting to watch all at the same time.

Fascinating - if a bit macabre.. Different religion - and different rituals. Take it all at face value, and (if you can) have a guide who can tell you what is going on. The buildings are a world heritage site - but everyday life (& mainly death) is transacted there by everyday Nepalis. Look out for the holy men and the monkeys.
Like a movie. Once in a lifetime experience that makes you want to become an anthropologist and understand better the ritual processes. DO NOT MISS!

30th Anniversary Trip. We found it interesting and similar to the events in Varanasi. It was a different visual perspective because you look down towards the crematorium. The huge temples surrounding and the bussle of the people had us just sitting for at least an hour people watching.
Great thanks,
Max and Lora Collins

Somber. Not for youngsters, faint of heart, etc. This can be very emotional. Cremation is the customary way of disclosing of the earthly body in Nepal. A friend brought us here. He had arranged for university student studying anthropology to be our guide. Just part of the tourist economics in Nepal. People make their own arrangements. We were fortunate.The site is split by a river. On one side is were the the family of the deceased goes through the ritual process preparing the body for cremation and the actual burning takes place. On the the opposite side are the tourists, monks, holyman and boys, and observers. There are a number of sites along a wharf like restraining wall where each cremation takes place. There a number in process in different stages. Our guide told us that the cremation can take 7-8 hours to complete.After the fire has consumed the remains the ashes are pushed into the river. The site bisected along the axis of the river into the royal and rich section, up stream and the economy section (lower cost). It was an emotional experience, you felt like you were intruding on a private matter and you were. Family members were very emotional and outgoing, oblivious to all of the people watching from the other side of the water.The holy men an boys were pure carnival. Their elaborate makeup, clothing, and antics made for good theater and seemed out of place. They want to be paid for everything. Using my 300mm lens to record a group of these men that appeared to taking a break and talking, seemed innocent until one spotted me and they all started running to close the 100+ feet wanting to be paid. I shook the first ones hand and then showed them a picture of a monkey on a rooftop I had taken earlier. I felt like I scammed the scammers.We thanked our guide and gave him the aged upon gratuity.

Educational. We went around with a guide who was a Hindu Indian and was very informative. I would highly recommend paying a guide to explain what was going on, it enhances the experience. Good experience.

Most someone take photos on a site like this?. Everytime, like in Varanassi, we ask ourselves the same question. Although the answer always is yes, we do not feel really comfortable. For us it is not necessary to say more.

Interesting and thought provoking. As a westerner, it is a very unusual sight to see bodies burning at the side of the river, and I wasn't quite prepared for it.But this is most certainly an experience and I think it's good to understand other cultures and see how they mourn their dead. Very sad to see, but it's something I will remember forever.

Very different. For people from our back ground the sight of cremations in public was an interesting sight.It was not our right to judge a religous practice that is centuries old. You will have to judge the specticale for your self!!!

Very sad but beautiful.. I had watched a Documentary on Hinduism and the cremation ceremony not too long before visiting Nepal. However, nothing will prepare you for it. Watching the family of the 3 year old girl, washing her lifeless body and pouring holy milk in to her mouth, was very upsetting yet very humbling. The ideology behind the whole ceremony is truly beautiful.

A Unique/Rare Experience. This religious ceremony is very foreign to westerners. It reminds one, how different cultures can be. The loved one's body is wrapped, then carried to the readied-platform and covered in flower garlands. Rituals are performed before the body is covered in straw and lit. After 2 or 3 hours the ashes are washed into the Holy River.

Very interesting Hindu temple. This is a very interesting Hindu temple, Pashupatinath. It is considered one of the holiest Hindu temples and is the main temple in Kathmandu.The people are dipped in the Bagmati river, which is extremely polluted, and then cremated. You should dress respectfully. You will see the ceremony from the opposite bank quite clearly. It is the main cremation place for Hindus so there is almost always a creation taking place. Non Hindus do not get access to the temple. Sometimes there is a charge of 1000 Nepali rupees and sometimes not.
Local Customs. An intrinsic part of life in this culture - a moving experience, they are building a crematorium nearby the avoid the pollution, but something will be lost when that is in use.
