Fascinating slice of life. But not foreigner friendly.. Bodies burn while mourning family and brightly clad sadhus watch. Unfortunately there is a charge for tourists, and if your are not from the Indian continent, forget about the main attraction. Pashupati Nath temple is off limits to foreigners, so the tourist fee is wasted. The river is also terribly water polluted, as is the air in all of Katmandu. Better to leave this site to the locals. :-(
It is inside Pashupatinath Temple. A good location or a must visit for the Hindus...may not necessaries for none Hindus..May be good to explore more..

Must see and experience. It is privilege to be allowed to see and share in this experience. The grounds are laid out so you see the repetition, the continuing on, and it brings such a meaning to this powerful place.

Interesting and unsual. macabre for a westerner but extremely fascinating, a favourite place to visit to fully be engaged in another culture and religion. one tip: please dress respectfully since you will most likely be watching a funeral and the crematoria is open air so do have your clothes washed afterwards because they do end up smelling like the funeral smoke.

My favorite place in Kathmandu. Most quite, calm and high energy place which I ever visit. All time when I'm in Nepal I'm going to that temple... Just to think, relax... may be kind of meditate... There two parts which is divide by Bagamati river. One part where is Shiva Temple - if you are not hindu, you anyway can't go inside, and place for cremation... where is very hard to be. And another part with stupas. Bright side. It's like hell and paradise... Full power!I can recommend to go there at night with many reasons: 1. There no people, no tourists, no sellers, no fake-sadhu. Just almost nobody. Dogs, monkeys and may some cremations... You can seat and think about eternally. 2. At night time visit of Pashupatinath is free ))Enjoy!

The mystical and spiritual Hindu cremation site in Kathmandu. On the banks of Bagmati River (a tributary of the Ganges River), at the Pashupatinah Temple (a temple dedicated to a manifestation of Lord Shiva), you will find the holy cremation site of Kathmandu. The temple is barred to non-hindus (as most of them are), but cremation rituals can be seen from the opposite bank. Dress properly and show respect. The cremation rituals are very impressive, offering a unique opportunity of understanding the Hindu faith.I visited Kathmandu on February 2015, nearly two and a half months before the terrible earthquake that devastated Nepal. Recent reviews by fellow travelers state that "The Crematoria" operates normally.
Local Crematoria. Very Unique how to see the body crematoria, before put into fire they wash it out and clean by Bagmati river as symbol, bring your masker because of the dust.
Peaceful and educational. For those who are not familiar with Hindu customs, this is a wonderful place. Not at all what one imagines. Best to have a guide with you.
Highlight of the trip.. Wow...You can view the ceremony as it is happening, it's kind dark yet beautiful at the same time. Definitely something worth experiencing

AMAZING SIGHTS. Most westerners have to stay on the opposite bank of the river as the far side is off limits to non Hindus - the views are great even though it can be a little macabre to see bodies being burnt - I put my camera away out of respect and just wanted to remember what I saw
Serene. This is an experience you should indulge. Actually seeing a cremation ceremony. The body will be cremated by the river bank.

Cultural shocks!. Excellent cultural introduction for your foreigner friends! This views of cremation of Hindus rituals is life time experiences as they are shockingly different. Some of friends are astonished from the rituals and also some of them very shocked too.

Be respectful and if you're non hindu, don't expect to be let in.. Not a place to be taking pixs! Considered one of the holiest places for Hindus, this is where many of them come to die. They are burned here on a pyre and the ashes let into the Bagmati River where it meets the Ganga river in India. Non Hindus are not allowed inside because many of them eat beef, this is by the temple of Lord Shiva. Come and observe but be respectful!

Cremation on the bank of holy river. went yesterday with a friend from USA. It is actually a place where we get knowledge of our life and reality. It might be new for the people from other parts of the world cause dead bodies are cremeted in the bank of river with firewood.

The Circle. These are not an attraction and i am not comfortable comparing Pasupatinath on the Bagmati with Benares on the Ganges. Both rivers are considered suitable holy rivers for the ashes of beloved family members to be transmuted into the incorruptible and be born away by the river to the vast Ocean waters from which we came. It is emblematic of the consciousness leaving the physical body and merging with the Super Consciousness which we are told never dies because it was never created. It simply IS, and we are a part. Many cultures and religions use this method of dealing with the human vessel of the consciousness especially in areas where the ground is too hard by sun or ice-.This method gives a sense of completion on many levels. The family is able to give their attention to the deceased,and fulfill the necessary religious rituals.This advances the process of grieving and allows healing of the mind and emotions to commence. I had become ill in Deli and flew to the nearest bathroom.There was a large rat there with the longest yellow teeth I had ever seen. Our eyes met. His were hopeful +gleaming. I got the message. "So why are you here?" he was telegraphing " Get on with it.". Suddenly i felt better.

A bit disturbing but interesting. A bit of a disturbing element of Hindu culture, but worth seeing - you look at the ceremony from a distance, so there's little chance of you seeing something that would turn your stomach upside down. Surprisingly, you can take pictures.
Must See. This was an amazing experience to learn more about the Hindu religion and their beautiful rituals after death. Unlike Varanasi, you are able to take photos of the cremation process.

Very fascinating, yet emotional!. What a different experience! You can feel quite uncomfortable and emotional being able to openly watch how this culture handles death, yet you cant help but be very intrigued. Being able to see and respect other ways of dealing with death is an eye-opener!
Deep experience. Much rawer than Varanasi, people here much more emotional, and the experience is totally different. Here you are allowed to take pictures, but not get close to the cremations...

Cremation Ghats at Pashupatinat. Fascinating and pretty basic. Health to see the reality of life and death all at a glance. be respectful... it is a Holy place to many people and should be treated as such.

Not for the faint hearted. Totally amazing experience, watching a custom so out of my normal boundaries!
Sad, feeling I should not be here, but watching on in sympathy

Emotional. This is a far smaller place than the one on the Ganges in Varanasi but no less moving. It makes you think about your mortality, not only because of the crematorium but also because of the surroundings.

closer to life. Some people may say it is inappropriate to 'sight see' during others' time of grief; but in the West we are so removed from the reality of life and death that I found it enlightening to witness the ceremony and ritual of saying goodbye and the continued remembrance. Grief does not disappear in a set time span and in the UK life carries on as normal in outward appearance. We could all learn a lot from Eastern culture that brings family together and remembers traditional rituals that value life. If you have the chance to visit the Crematoria don't dismiss it as macabre or inappropriate.

$10 entry fee for foreigners. They charge $10 entry fee for foreigners per person. We didn't go inside. The fee is outrages and it seems that the real purpose of the fee is to keep foreigners away from this place. Well, it worked we didn't go.

Moving experience. Difficult to choose a rating - since it should really read "Extraordinary"; we were told that the buildings along the river take the elderly and they progress along the river bank from the equivalent of Care Home to Hospice before passing ultimately to the Crematoria. A funeral pyre was alight when we visited and it was the unusual smell which we first noticed, then somewhat horrified suddenly realised that it was a body; after this the remains are tipped into the river, with much venting of emotion by the male members of the family who actually guided it in the river. A different culture and a mixture of shock and compulsive viewing!

A good place to die.. The cremations along this river are a Hindu rite that goes back thousands of years. The remains of the dead body are released on the river after the Atman *soul( is released from the body during cremation. I look at this and feel that this would be a good place to die.
Last rites. The last rites of Hindu cremation is observed here. Many foreigners who are not allowed into the temple, gather here to witness some of th rituals that are observed in the precinct.

Something to see and ponder. This is the place where all nepali hindus end they journey on earth. It is a sacred place, so respect has to be shown. It is much smaller than the Varanisi crematoria, but it has a more intimate feeling. Spent some time looking quietly from across the river. It will make you reflect on life and death.

Burning of the deads. The crematoria can be the newest experience for the tourist. The place where you can see the dead bodies being burnt down and various after death Hindu rituals carried down. Though it is sad thing to see others being burnt but it is a totally new experience for non Hindu tourist. Good thing about this area is that you can take the photographs of the dead. Your Rs 1000 entry for the Pashupatinath area will be worth it. Watching the dead for 2-3 hours until it fully turned into ashes made me know the meaning of life.

Must see.... Witnessing the cremation of a family's loved one is a sobering experience, but part of understanding how folk in Kathmandu say goodbye. Visiting this place is definitely not for every tourist, as its quite confronting, makes you feel uncomfortable, and possibly like a callous observer. We had a group guide who explained the significance of each step in the ceremony, so we felt less like we were staring, and more like we were trying to appreciate what was happening. A deceased person is carried on a bier to the steps of the river, laid at an angle so his/her feet touch the water, to make a physical connection to the river. Family say their last goodbyes, then the deceased is taken to the wood pyre. Some stone areas are reserved for royalty. Not taking photos is an essential sign of respect. Visiting theses places adds to your appreciation of the significance of the holy river in religious values.

Not a sightseeing spot. The Burning Ghat is the first sight that we are faced with before entering the Pashupatinath Temple complex.The Ghat is on the Baghmati river. Hindus cremate their dead here. It has become a spectacle for visitors and tourists....However, the sight of a dead body being burnt, reminds us about the impermanence of our own body and makes us reflect on the purpose of life. This is certainly not a sightseeing spot.

The Crematoria. Please do not think of this as sightseeing. Or an attraction This is a sacred place where. Grief stricken people say goodbye to their loved ones. The services are very dignified with the body being washed and prepared for the funeral pyre. Some tourists are very ghoulish. Please respect the Budhist Hindu traditions. Watch in reverence as you would at a funeral in your own country. A new modern crematorium as we would recognise it is being built. But I think the traditional method will be used for a long time It is a very humbling experience to visit this place and it will remind you of your own mortalityOn a lighter note when I was there ambulances would arrive bringing the dead on litters to take to the funeral pyres from one ambulance came an old man with a long white beard wrapped in white cloth. Poor soul I thought. Making his way to be cremated. All of a sudden he waved a bony hand. my God I thought. He is not dead. Then I was informed that he was being taken to the hospital round the corner. Puts a twist on the old saying. In the midst of death we are in life. Go and watch in reverence. Remember nothing in the universe is permanent. Namaste
strange feeling. tourists have to pay to see the dead people ceremony. interesting to know but for some people can be quite hard to watch the farewell of a family.

A sacred crematorium for the Hindu people. We visit the Crematoria , on 2 January 2015 , in part of the historical city tour arranged by Outshine Adventures.The history was told by our knowledgeable Nepali guide ,Mr Prasant.The Crematoria is located beside the Bagmati river, in the Pashupatinath temple complex.This site is a very important for the Nepal and India people ,many people arrive here to find shelter ,wait for the the last several weeks of their lives, to meet death.Bodies of the dead also brought here ,with cleaning and mourning rituals,could be seen.Later they be cremated on the banks of the river and travel their last journey with the waters of the sacred river Bagmati, which later meets the holy river Ganges. This is a place, with special atmosphere of death, death is present in almost every ritual and every sight in here.This place might not a place for everybody.We witnessed the crematory, mourning ,bathing process of the deceased , from the riverbank just opposite the crematoria , and the Pashupatinath main temple.A religious ,cultural and sacred place to be , we feel moved when watching the whole process , in fact , its the 1st open air crematory process we witnessed in our lifetime.Hopefully this magnificent area are spared during the earthquake and the aftershocks.

a sight to see. After seeing the one on the Ganges this one is a little smaller but still a sight. it smelled a bit at this location likely due to the garbage on the side upon which we were standing across the river. they perform a sacred ritual and it is a cultural thing that is to be respected.

Sobering insite into Hindu culture. To observe the ritual of the cremation of Hindus was very solemn. The ritual of cleaning the body by relatives and then the actual cremation made me reflect on the mortality of us all. I actually felt privileged to watch the ceremonies.

World heritage site.. I think this place (Pushupathi) will be working day and night to cope with the number of dead in Kathmandu. We visited before the earthquake and were lucky enough to witness a cremation of an ex-soldier. There was a company of Gurkhas who played the last post and presented arms at the ceremony. I must admit to feeling a little like a gatecrasher intruding on another family's grief but was one of hundreds who had come to watch the spectacle.

burning desire to go there! people are dying to go there!!!!!. it was a great place very busy but worth a visit it kind of makes you think about your own demise. smells like a gianl BBQ but a great experience.

Disturbing. For better understanding, we, Westeners need to see how "the other half lives,- and dies". And this is just the place. The smoke from the funeral pyres can be a bit overwhelming and the fact that all the remains, including offerings etc are thrown into the river, is disturbing. This waterway is nothing more than a floating garbage tip. Maybe other people see it differently.

Interesting. Some would probably be horrified but I found this a very interesting place to visit. You could see the bodies being carried to the river (under a blanket) and burned when the family and friends were watching. To be cremated there was clearly a huge honor and our nepali friend who guided us said that ge hoped to be cremated there aswell when his day comes.Also the big golden rooftop is beautiful to look at even if I, a non-hindu, can't go inside the gates.

Same as Pashupatinath temple. My review was for Pashupatinath was for this place as well. It is connected. One large area to see the Crematora, the temple, the fertility shrines, the holy men etc...This was the most interesting place I visited.

A moment of reflection. Though it is much smaller than the setup in Varanasi, it is just as emotional and moving an experience to witness the many bodies burning and all the rituals involved. The encounter with sadhus willing to have their photos taken for a few rupees brings you right back to earth. Worth the visit on many levels...

From ashes ... To ashes. While cremation has become more common in the Western World it is something that most Westerners have never seen or experienced in a close-up setting. The Crematoria is located at the Pashupatinath temple on the banks of the Bagmati River. As we entered the crematory area the smoke from multiple cremations hung heavy in the air as the scent of the fires and burning bodies filled the air. It's a strange sensation to watch a Hindu cremation ceremony for the first time, but it's also a cultural experience you can't take your eyes off of.

One day my body will be also ...... Being a Hindu ,we need to come similar place after death. So this is different experience. You can feel what is life and what is end of life. .was very thoughtful after coming here.

An eye opening experience.. If you have ever experienced hindu crematorium, this is a must.They have an ashram for elderly with no family.There are saddu everywhere. Cremation takes place throughout the day.It's a busy place but they do charge foreigners am entrance fee.

A very spiritual and moving experience. Such an amazing and moving experience. I felt very privileged to witness the rituals performed by the Hindu people as they prepared the bodies of their loved ones. The strong scent of the burning bodies was quite confronting, but the experience as a whole was one I will never forget. An amazing cultural in-site, that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

Witness with respect and gain a little understanding. As In Varanassi on the Ghats I was struck by how differently we deal with death and the proximity of the crematation yet still be able to obseve respectfully .Its such a thought provoking experience and a world away from the shps and bars of Thamel .

Moved. A very moving experience. In the West we are so cut off from death. This is real, and very, very beautiful. Spend time at the Crematoria – it is no place for a quick visit – and allow yourself to be touched by the extraordinary ritual of families ministering to the dead. We have to much to learn here in the West.

Respectful. In the Hindu religion, for the funeral, they take the dead bodies to a cremation spot on the river at the holy site to cremate the bodies in public. Watching the cremation process was something that one will always remember.
Amazing. Never seen a real cremation and was overwhelmed by the process. Also helped by the guidance and explanations by my excellent guide.

Very special...very solemn. We were able to see the full process from bringing in the body, wrapping it in cloth, adorning it with flowers, and then moving it to the place of cremation. I was really moved by this entire process and how it was filled with respect and love for the departed.
Expensive entry ticket. It's ok to see what's going on but we basically just did a quick walk around. Don't forget your masks. Don't shoot photos of saddhus unless you want to pay up

You have to see it to believe it!. Part of the death process in Hindu is to burn the body of the deceased family member. In the West this process would be very private and personal...not so in the Hindu religion. They take the bodies to a cremation spot on the river at the holy site (next to the temple) to cremate the bodies in public. There are stands set up to view and photograph this process and the family members are well aware and not offended by the recording of this ceremony. However, I will say it was a bit disturbing watching this in person from Western Eyes. The bodies are cremated 3-48 hrs after death and the eldest son or male in the family conducts the ceremony. The body is prepared and set on a cremation platform and burned until there are only ashes and no recognizable body parts. The family member walks around the body three times with the flame in hand and the fire is started in the mouth. The cremation usually takes about 3 hours for full consumption. After the cremation the ashes (and anything left) is swept into the river. The other seemingly strange thing about this is, there are young men that comb the silt (the river is very shallow and barely moving) beneath the cremation platforms to recover any gold (mostly from dental work) or jewelry not consumed by the fire. There's another set of young men that recover the charred wood from the river and take it to the brick furnaces. The cremation cost 10 dollars on the right side of the bridge and 20 dollars on the left side of the bridge because it's closer to temple. The cremations go on 24hrs a day and there are always bodies waiting to be cremated.

Expensive entrance fee. Watching the cremation process was something that we will remember for the rest of our lives. The only downside is the relatively steep 1000 RP entrance fee. Be prepared to pay if you accept the invite of some Brahmin (?) to take pictures based on what I've observed.
Reflective. A place to reflect and appreciate. We were hassled by beggars and people wanting to be our guides which took away from the experience

Slightly macabre, but fascinating. Very unique experience, seeing the cremation of people carefully wrapped in shrouds. There are a few phony yogis, but they still are worth the tip for the unique photo. The monkeys are cheeky and the continual smoky smell reminds you of what is going on. WORTH the visit

Not a touristic site . Show respect for the place. It's not just another touristic site. I saw other tourists constantly talking with each other and taking photographs of the ceremony and not being aware that they are just attending someone's funeral and this is where the families grief.It's where the burning of body on Ghats by bagmati river takes place. Be prepared for the smell of burning flesh. Be prepared to see some intense moments of grief, cry and someone's tears.

Never again!. This a very personal comment and in no way reflects on the actual practises carried out nor the guide who took us there. I didn't want to go there but it was part of our organised tour. I tried to keep away from the main area but it just isn't posisble - you have to walk along the river, you have to walk past the waiting pyres etc. I left the group and waitied in the temple which is adjacent to the crematorium but even so the sounds and smells are impossible to avoid. A child's cremation took place whilst our group (of 3) was there and everyone was very upset afterwards. I really and truly think this should be an fully optional part of a tour. I am very sensitive on this subject for personal reasons and I would highly recommend tour companies to re-plan their itineraries and give visitors the choice of missing this out entirely.

Interesting place. The crematoria is located near the Pashupatinath Temple, on the banks of the Bagmati River. As per Hindu tradition, body is cremated on death. Although it is common for a Indians, the crematoria makes for a interesting visit while you visit the Pashupatinath Temple. Make sure you stay far away from the place and kindly avoid taking photographs as it may be invading privacy especially at the time of grief.

A Must See in Kathmandu, Nepal. I am an American in Kathmandu, Nepal on business. I had a day off so I took the opportunity to obtain a guide and tour some of the temples. I visited the Pashupatinath Temple which is near the place where the Hindu people are cremated. I felt like I was intruding on this deeply private type of ceremony, but I was assured by my business associates, who live in Kathmandu, that this was not the case. I did not stay for long because quite frankly it is very depressing watching corpses burn. I do however recommend that you include this on your list of things to see in Kathmandu, Nepal.

not pleasant, but very interesting. Take a guide at the entrance to temple complex, be ready to pay, but he will explain you everything about the ceremony. Very unusual for europeans. It's difficult to believe that this is the true life.

Interesting and up close. We viewed the Crematoria just across a small stream at the temple complex and were able to witness the whole process of building and decorating the funeral pyres to the processions of families bringing their loved ones to rest.

Amazing and spiritual. If you dont want to smell because there is lots of burning bodies, you dont have to go there.But if you have respect for other religions and people you can go and observe how the funeral in Hindu culture looks like.Great place but not for everyone.
Crematoria. This is completely different to anything else you will see. The way in which they deal with theie deceased is amazing. But be warned, the is a smell that goes with it

Not for the squeamish. You need to see this soon before the authorities set up their permanent crematorium. This is where the Hindu community say goodbye to their loved ones on the Ghats. Be prepared to see scenes of intense human grief, the wood fire burnings of white cloth wrapped human bodies and the smell of burning flesh. What is amazing is that nobody seems to mind the tourists watching this incredibly personal situation - not even the taking of photographs. I find it deeply intrusive to take photos of such intensely personal things but most tourists don't seem to care - the participants don't mind either.If you go to Kathmandu, you need to see this once- never twice - oh yes- watch out for the monkeys!

Very impressive. It's not every day that you get to see such an impressive ritual. In the western world we are not used to deal with death in such a direct way. So, be prepared to see some shokking images.To see all this you have to pay 1.000 roepies per person. A lot of money to Nepalees standards.As my husband payed the tickets we were appoached by a young man who showed us the site and the temples. Het was very friendly and explained everything. We liked him a lot. We thought he was part of the 'package'. After he showed us everthing, including the old-peopleshome, he demanded 10 dollars. We were stunned. And all of a sudden he was not that nice anymore.This spoiled our visit somewhat.

Amazing Visit. Our host took us the the Crematoria after an early morning flight up to Mt. Everest. It made for quite a diverse day of sightseeing in Kathmandu. It was fascinating to hear of the rituals and traditions of how the Hindu funeral process was so tied to the life of the individual.

The Sadhus priests are like rock stars here. You are in the 1 of the most holy of places in all of Nepal here. The sacred river flows through Kathmandu here and at least 30 people per day who have died are burned for 4-5 hours and cremated every day. The smoke is thick and be prepared for true grieving for the loss of loved ones. They just are more open about it than we are and more tolerant for curious onlookers. I on the other hand was a participant in this amazing ceremony. I had brought some of my brothers ashes from the USA and my guide and the Sadhus holy men helped me achieve a proper send off on this sacred river. We put some of my brothers ashes in a bowl of grasses with flowers and incense burning. The painted up faces holy men said a prayer for me and my brother. Come here if you are really curious about life and death through Hindu theology. A++++++
Wow wasnt ready for this one. Our guide took us at dusk, it was eerie and amazing. Our guide was so knowledgeable we learned so much, a fascinating place, the monkeys are scary though.

Death dealt with in a beautiful way. I find Hindu rituals quite beautiful and appreciate the way death is dealt with in this context (I don't find it shocking or macabre). I also think that Pashupatinath is a beautiful place and well worth the visit (the river itself is a little sad). However, since you have to pay 10 USD to get in, I've only done it once and have very little desire to do it again. But if you have the money and if you're interested in Hindu culture and death rituals, then it's definitely worth seeing. There are lots of "guides" available, some more knowledgeable than others and it's up to you to decide whether you're interested in their services or not. If you do decide to "hire" one, it might be a good idea to negotiate the price beforehand. You can easily spend a couple of hours here.

$10 to see a sight you will NEVER forget. There's more here than just the crematoria. This is a park-like hangout for some of the locals, a Hindu temple, the deer park, and of course the "crazy-face" guys. Take your selfie with them for sure! The main attraction is seeing the cremations in progress. Its a somber and moving sight. And when the wind shifts you are going to be "smoked". So now you will be able to say that you inhaled a bit of someone's corpse! Bet you can't get that back home.

Welcome to reality!. None of us wants to die and when we see a body being taken for its last rites, our minds conveniently tell us that this would not happen with us. Reality strikes only when someone, we love, leaves us forever. This is the time we realise that Death is as real and inevitable; and not so much in our hands as birth.My visit to Crematoria was one of such experience where I brushed with life's most stark truth, i.e. death!I had gone to Pashupatinath temple (earlier also, twice I have been there, but never had this experience) and while going around the temple I saw people gathered around a wall. Everyone was watching something going on below. I couldn't curb my curiosity and I also tried to look down.What I saw filled me with mixed feelings. After a while I realised that my eyes were moist. Some politician's mother had died and the whole family had gathered there. I watched the whole ceremony starting from giving a wash to the departed body and then some religious rituals before the body is put on a pyre, decorated with bright yellow marigold flowers. A person who was loved by many, who had a life, was no more there. There was fire, high flames and a bunch of people who were crying and hugging each other; and a whole lot of onlookers who had gathered around the area to watch the last journey.I came out of the temple feeling humbled, I was quiet, I had witnessed the eternal truth!A visit to Crematoria is worth giving a go if you believe in life and death!

Interesting, but just a little bit creepy.... Watching people say goodbye to their dead and then burning them is just a bit macabre, but it is worth seeing.I would put it on par with the bones in Paris. Worth seeing and understanding another religion, but wouldn't put it as a must do - especially if you are a bit squeamish.

Fire for the soul. I originally felt a bit ghoulish about going here but it turned out to be an interesting day. The religious beliefs, cremation rituals and colourful yogis make for an experience you won't get at home. Make sure you respect the space and grief of the people attending for their love ones.

Well it's not Everyone's Cup of Tea. This place might not be to everyone's liking, but it really is worth a visit. Mind you I did think the 1000NR entrance fee was somewhat expensive. Do yourself a favour and allow a guide to show you around and explain everything that goes on, costs for us was 20USD. Basically this place is an open air crematorium - you do see bodies being burnt on a pyre then pushed into the river. But for me it really didn't seem macabre. The way everything was explained to us put things into a different prospective. This really is an unusual place to either describe, approve of of disapprove of. Please do visit and make your own opinion.
I feel sad. I feel sad when seeing people cry for their love one, you may sit and reflect about life and death, but if you want to take photos, please don't go too close.

A worthwhile see. I had wanted to visit here on my last trip esp for the crematoria area - it is not morbid at all, but a beautiful celebration of the circle of life. A very peaceful place and far from intrusive as I thought it might be. Sitting across the river, the whole area feels steeped in history. Where ancient meets modern. Wonderful to see. It is however very expensive for tourists to visit - now 1000, which I felt to be very, very steep :-(. I was glad to see though.

A Fascinating Experience. Visiting the crematoria was truly a unique and fascinating experience. It also gave us a great insight into the Nepalese culture and hindu rituals. Hiring a guide is also recommended as they will explain the cremation stages as well as all of the religious aspects.

Excuse to rip off tourists. They are ripping off tourists at The Crematory! As soon as I got there to visit the place, I was informed that the entrance fee was 1.000 NPR which correspond more or less to U$10.00. It’s a quite high value for Nepalese standards. According to the banner attached at the counter, this charged value would be used for renovation and maintenance of the Temple and Monuments. I understand it but, I cannot understand why just tourists have to pay this entrance fee. A guide explained to me that local people don’t pay because they do voluntary job there. It became in my mind a perfect excuse to rip off tourists since I’m sure that almost anybody in Kathmandu is working for free there. I refused paying this abuse and came back to my hostel frustrated. If you want to see a Crematory, go to India (Varanasi). A week ago I saw a huge Crematory for free.

very moving and atmospheric. We felt very priviledged to witness the funerals taking place and would urge you to go look and learn for yourselves. this is not a morbid experience, we actually found it more uplifting than a traditional western funeral.

Emotional scene. Place where traditional cremation takes place. There were kid and an old man being prepared for cremation when we visited. The whole scene was emotional and spiritual.
A very touching and unusual experience.

Sombre and serene. Respect for those grieving is an easy thing to observe at this place. At the same time, the events and setting provide ample reason for reflection on the nature of life and where it ends. The rituals of life are important for all of us even when we are simply observers and not active participants; take some tome at this place to remember what is important
Fire for peace !!!. According to Hinduism or anyother religion life is built up of nature, giving back to nature what you took from it is harmonious and in accord to nature.

Hindu education. First.... do not take the first tour guide who rushes up to you and trys to guilt you into paying a lot because the ticket price is high. WAIT.... get the 300 rupee guides further in. With a good guide you will learn a lot. Not for the squeamish. They are burning bodies there daily. A good guide puts it into perspective.

One of a kind touristy place.. It might bother some but if you don't mind seeing the dead burn right in front of your eyes then this is one of the unique experience. Is the most scared and holiest place evern though is a cremation place. They will wash the dead in the river then they will sue the river water to wash the head and feet of the one alive.

Very surreal!. At the time of my visit there were at least 6 funeral pyres with remains being swept into the river! Initially it was quite daunting but there was a very dignified atmosphere involved! This is a World Heritage site with a significant number of "attractions" ranging from the adjacent hospice, hundreds of monkeys,stunning views and " interesting" people openly smoking hashish!

Interesting.... It was a good place to visit to get a sense of the culture. This is the most holy place for Hindus to get cremated. However, you literally watch fires burning that you know are bodies and you breath in the smoke, which isn't particularly more rancid than other smoke, except you know you're breathing in human ash. there's an interesting Temple next to the crematorium that was built to honor a phallic shaped stone, so there was a lot of phallus related symbols and statues everywhere. I thought it was funny, but others may be dismayed.

Good cultural experience. Overall, it's definitely a must to visit just to take in the religious experience of the hindu culture. You don't need to spend more than a hour there as there isn't much to do other than view from a distance some of the religious ceremonies. It's a bit eerie overall watching families perform ceremonies along the river for their loved ones that have passed away. We had a tour guide that we hired inside the grounds for $10 USD, which we heard was the going rate and was reasonable for a group of 4 of us. It's not needed to have a guide, but we found it useful to learn more of the history behind the religious ceremonies. You could also just follow one of the large tourist groups walking around and listen in on the information provided by their guide which is what we did for the first 30 minutes or so.

Interesting to see funerals in other cultures.. The crematoria is a confronting place - dead people are wrapped in gauze blessings given flowers sprinkled over the body then laid on a pyre and lit up - confronting but interesting to see how others do funerals - felt almost voyeuristic watching an intensely private moment of a family but apparently a normal thing in Nepal.

Meet the dead. Culturally fascinating, but for westerners the visibility of dead bodies throughout the various ceremonies could be educational or confronting depending on your perspective (especially for young) children. Having a local guide that can explain the customs/ceremonies is valuable.

Interesting experience. Katmandu is an interesting city with very narrow streets that are shared with many motorbikes and cars. Good shopping for knitters, silk pashminas and scarves, jewellery. Lots of good eating places, some in courtyards. Went to many temples and the zoo was interesting - very small.

A very unique experience. Nothing quite prepares a person who is visiting a cremation site - especially for the first time. Up to 12 priers burning simultaneously, smoke everywhere, monkeys, sacred river, gurus galore....

The person was loved.... The stark reality of this experience was somewhat surreal. Yes death is inevitable, but here it is perceived as the start of a spiritual journey. It was interesting to watch the ceremony from a distance alongside the Bagmati River and in the compound of the great Pashupatinath Temple. I first saw the smoke before I saw the funeral pyre and the straw above the body and the logs beneath it. There was a clear reverence surrounding the site from those present. The person was loved...

May bother some. Yes, it is a public crematoria that may bother some visitors. If it is looked at just another ritual, how other cultures handle death, it is easier to accept. I certainly learned much when I went with my guide. Very informative.

Informative view of cultural differences. It was interesting to watch 2 funeral ceremonies and cremations from across the filthy river. The actual fire under the bodies was a startling visual which upset some of our group. The reality of it all was definitely brought home to everyone. This is NOT for everyone, but I am so glad we experienced this. Also, the contrast between what we do and what they do was absolutely stunning.

Another vieuw on death.. In Pasupathinath you can see and follow the cremations from Hindu-people from close-by.Iff you heve somebody with you who can explain you all the rituals, it is less scary then you might think. In a matter of fact, the cremation is very interesting to follow.Always remember that this is not the end but just a transformation to a new life.What is left when the soul is gone, is just the body and somehow you have to get rid of that also.Cremation is a good and clean and healthy option to do so. The surrounding buildings are nice and impressive. The Shiva-tempel is not accessable for non-hindu's.The outside of the building and the surrounding area are surtainly worth a visit.Entrancefee is approx.10 euro / 13 USD.

May be troubling to some. Although some of our group found this site troubling, I thought it was interesting. Cremations in Nepal are a public affair and this was a chance to experience one (or more).

Eye opener. Watching the cremation at the shores of the Bagmati river is definitely eye opening. Once dead we are just a dead body after all. Going back to ashes which are then dissolved into the river. But during the aarti time at 6:00- 6:30pm it is a lovely experience. You feel the vibes being so close to Lord Shiva.

A mixture of the fascinating and the macabre. This is a very large temple complex (there is a fee to visit) but unfortunately the main large hindu temple is only open to hindus! On the up side there is still a lot to visit. On the down side the gurus have become a tourist attraction (you have to pay to take any photos with them!). The cremation ceremonies are round the clock with ash split in the river which has become filthy not just because of the ash but also major amount of rubbish.Still worth a visit!

Great experience. It was such a solemn experience to view how the end of life is met in the traditional Hindu way. There are slight variations depending on where the deceased is from.
There are painted holy men sitting above this area that get upset if you take their picture without paying them.

Cultural 10/10. For people with a open view on live and death.
Beautiful yo see how these people handle to passing of a loved one.
Amazing area, but be careful at the entrance they try to trick you with the entrance fee.
This the place to make pictures!

Sad and interesting. Should go. Please respect the people there, stay from a distance if you want to take pictures. This is the most expesive place to visit (around USD 10). If you enter from the exit you don't need to pay anything. They only make tourists pay.
END OF D DAY !!. Dis place is located just behind Pashupatinath Temple. It will make you realize about NOTHING WILL LAST FOREVER. You can experience Creation process of Hindu culture.

Fascinating.. We visited the temple and the crematoria, as a westerner I felt a little awkward watching someone elses funeral, but that was just me.It's fascinating how they do things here, the cremation should take place within 24 hours, I think there were 8 - 10 platforms and professionals brush the last remains of someone from the platform into the river, the eldest son, or chief mourner then has to spend a period of weeks in isolation and mourning.Whilst we were there the male members of a family arrived with the deceased relative, wrapped in a white shroud, they then were supposed to take the deceased to the river and wash the body, but the family seemed at a loss as to what to do, they were even on mobile phones whilst down by the river.It's a strange experience, but one I'm glad I glimpsed, although we were on the opposite bank, I still felt as though I was intruding, but there were other Nepalis there as well.The Temple next door is a most sacred place for Hindu's and non Hindu's can't enter, but you can seen the Statue of the massive bull through the open doors and if you go up the path at the side, you can get a look at the interior from above.There are all sorts of animals there, from cattle, goats, monkey's to dogs. The area is also a World Heritage Site, with funds being spent on it. It helps to visit with a local guide who will give you all the history and details of the rituals.
Did not seem very interesting to me.. I do not know what all the fuss is about. Or maybe I was tired at the end of the day but it was not interesting to me and I just wanted to move on.

Interesting place.. We paid our 10000 rps to get in, we were hassled by guides to use their services.. But we went on alone, of course we couldn't go in the temple but the grounds around it. We walked for ten minutes and I felt I needed to know more about this place. So I engaged the services of a young man, 18 years old and very good English. I am glad I did as I learnt a lot about the life and death of people in Nepal. You will see dead bodies here, so be prepared. but I didn't feel we where intruding in the families grief..local young boys dive in looking for any metal brushed into the river off the funeral fire right under the noses of the next family.. you have to visit this place to understand the atmosphere. Beware for the fake holy men! Why would anyone give them money.. We saw a real holy man in mother Therasor's old folks home, he just prays and chants and feels no need to ask for money. And the monkeys are a wee bit aggressive.

Strange but worth seeing. Worth seeing and trying to understand. It's certainly strange for one from another culture to see bodies burned and their remains slid into the river. The same river where locals are bathing and who knows what???

A transcultural experience. We appreciated the solemn beauty and the insight into death in other cultures. The setting was incredible. Sounds odd - but we took our kids (9,11) from the opposite bank there is not too much 'detail' and its all very matter of fact - dare I say educational.Usual array of hawkers etc, monkeys everywhere - take a guide, if only just to keep other guides off.
Weird and wonderful. A truly unique experience. Difficult to judge how you will feel before you visit. An absolute must to visit. Will give you a great insight into Nepalise culture and rituals.
Chance to See Local Customs. The area was unique and offered a glimpse into the Hindu religious practices related to the funerals. We have been to Varanasi in India, and has very similar aspects.

Fascinating but confronting. We really enjoyed our trip to the Crematoria. The facility included a Sikhs temple, a crematorium, a fertility temple and an aged care facility. Pay the fee for a guide so you know what's what. (approx AUD$25). The crematorium is open for all to see. It was a confronting experience, as we were there at the actual time of the lighting of the fire. But put this on your to do list

A Cultural Experience. We had a guide who explained the whole Hindu was of cremation i.e taking the body back to where it had come from etc. I found this culturally interesting and not morbid at all. I had to laugh at the Holy men who would not have photo's taken but if you paid them they were okay :-)
Voyeuristic but fascinating. A most peculiar and sobering experience but definitely one to see if in Kathmandu. Watch out for the monkeys. they're big, unafraid and everywhere.

Interesting but morbid. The whole experience was a bit weird. If you want to see how the locals deal with their dead, the whole experience was fascinating, but quite morbid. If I was burying(cremating) my loved ones, I would be put off by all the tourists peering and taking pictures. I was also put off by the so called holy men painted up and begging people to take pictures of them for money. One painted up holy man, that was in nothing but a metal jock strap, was especially strange. I am also put off by the government charging a steep fee to enter the area, taking advantage of the people sending off their loved ones for the last time.
Surprisingly Fascinating. Watched the comings and goings from a distance and found it very surprisingly interesting, although the river looks anything but sacred.

Local Culture. It a must visit place to know a little bit more about nepali culture. It is not a beautiful place, neither has a good smell, but it is something very different from what ocidental culture is used to.

Visiting with respect. I am quite reluctant to give rating to it at the place....however, as a visitor to explore others culture, it is necessary to see and to feel together with the local, right? This is why I insist to give a rating. It is not attraction, but it is a place to understand more about local's culture. Visited 1994.

What an experiecte!. The old temple was fabulous but having the sacred opportunity to watch the dead being burned was beyond compare as a culture and religious experience. Would certainly recommend it to everyone and good to hire a guide as it helps the economy and they have great advise.

Check it out if you are curious. We went at the end of the day, after having visited all of the other religious sites in and around Kathmandu. I was annoyed at being charged 10USD to enter the site but had no access to the temple (Hindus only). We went along the water while bodies were being cremated. It was smoky, smelly and there was ash falling from the rice leaves and logs burning. We also saw the long-haired 'ghost men' who are all painted up, sitting around and wanting money for a photo. I guess it just wasn't my thing.... after a day of having paid entrance fees at every location, asked for donations all over the place, been followed by merchants everywhere and having to barter hard for any purchase. I just felt like this place was dirty and 'expensive'. Of all the sites we visited in six hours, this was probably the most interesting due to the cremation concept.

Once in a life time viewing but please remember that people are cremating loved ones.. So amazing to witness yet so sad at the same time. The smell of burning bodies was not that bad but the thought that you are breathing in their ash was unpleasant. A thought provoking place to spend an hour or so.
This is not a show.... I don't think no one is happy to see strangers taking pictures or watching you especially when you lost a love one. We should respect their culture and this moment of grieve.
impressive. you can follow the whole process from the bridge and take pictures if you want. they recently started to charge 10$ at the entrance in town.

Not Varanasi. Had visited the Pashupatinath area, but not being able to enter the temple, we spent more time walking opposite the main cremation "stations" and having our guide answer our questions about the practices and procedures.Having previously visited Varanasi, one has to say this was on a smaller scale, and less moving for that, plus here apparently the do not cremate at night.Still felt a visit was worthwhile, for the sights and sounds, including mischievous monkeys.

A sad place. Even though the crematoria was interesting, it was also sad to be there watching others grieve over lost ones. It seems if there is a buck to be made, it can be made at others expense. I felt like we should have not been there.

Peaceful place - time to reflect. Its surprising for me that a place where you see bodies getting cremated in the open can be so peaceful and give you time to reflect. Surprising but definitely a must visit. People do try to take Rs1000 from non-hindus to enter this place but plan well to skip through. No one should be charged for entering a place according to me.
Smelly and gruesome place. good only for necrophiles. Definitely to avoid for more sensible tourists! Not worth the ticket price.
Great cultural experience. Worth getting a guide (they hang around the entrance) to help explain the rituals and sights. You just need to give him a small donation of your choice at the end.

Well worth a visit, a humbling experience to say the least. Was a little hesitant about visiting at first, but glad i didWe had a really great guide, who explained all the details regarding the cremation stages and all the cultural/religious aspects, a great insight into the Hindu religion.

Very Interesting. We weren't sure at first if we would go to this site, but so glad we went. We were able to be a part of a police officers service, with a police band and such. It was very heartwarming, yet sad at the same time. It was good to see how a different religion deals with end of life.

Cultural experience. We were so fortunate to be able to witness a cremation from beginning to end. Our wonderful guide, Prob, explained all the stages of the cremation and other activities in the area such as traditional ceremonies conducted in remembrance of those who had died in the past. It was quite a spiritual feeling to follow the ceremony. The "Holy" men, dressed in ridiculous get ups and their bodies painted white, are a scam. As our guide told us, in his opinion, they weren't "holly", as they charged visitors to take a photo of them. We paid of course, just to get a snap of how odd they looked! I recommend this Cremation ceremony.

Be prepared for a culture shock. The visit to this site was very confronting so be prepared.It is totally commensurate with the religious and cultural beliefs of the Nepalese and must be respected but this very public way of dealing with cremation is very different to the private way we deal with it. It would not advise that it is a "must see" but it is a part of life in a Nepal.

The most culturally interesting place in Kathmandu. If there is one thing I will never forget about my 4 days in Kathmandu, it's this place. A very culturally interesting experience along the river close to Pashupatinath temple. As stated in most review, beware - you will see dead bodies.

Confronting and yet I was deeply interested. Within hours of passing family bring their loved ones here to this very public of places and yet mourn their loss and display their grief with us westerners watching and questioning. There is a sense of macabre and humor. I past a couple of hindu monks with barely anything on, and yet out pops a mobile phone from under a loin cloth - even here in this most ritualistic of places modern technology has found its place.

I didn't regret to pay entrance fee 1000R. To the crematoria you get take bus from Ratna Park (15R) and after you can continue to Bodnath stupa. Crematoria is sad, breathtaking and shocking place. Now entrance fee is 1000R, but I didn't regret to pay it. I spent hours watching burning bodies there and ceremonies there. If you come, on the left side there are cleaning ceremonies of the dead bodies and there is a place for burning rich people. On the right side there are many burning places. In this place you can realized how our bodies are easily transient. If you are in Kathmandu, find a half of the day and spend time there. It is worth.
Get at new view of life and death. This place is for the more, serious traveler, this place should be visited whit respect. Please look and observe that life is has an end

Interesting cultural experience. Take a deep breath if you're not a fan of seeing dead bodies. We saw a few - this is where the Hindu's of Nepal burn their dead. It's very interesting and well worth a visit. Watch out for tour guides - if they take you around and tell you stuff they'll want paying!

Visit but beware of scammers. This is well worth a visit, to see the bodies being brought for cremation being washed in the river prior to burning, fascinating to me as a westerner. Photos are allowed unlike in Varanasi, India. Lots of people offering guide services but charging high prices. Agree your price beforehand, I did but saw others that didn't have aggravation from the guides afterwards for saying their price was too expensive. The various holy men etc charge you for taking their photo and I was told that I couldn't go into a nearby temple as I wasn't the right religion, not sure how correct that is but check it out as I was charged for the ticket to the temple anyway! As it was raining hard I didn't protest too much, but I got a feeling of scamming throughout this area. Crematoria is cool though.

One for the locals. A culturally and spiritually significant site. All respect to the Nepalese. However this is not an attractive tourist destination. Sure there is the education angle, but I felt like I was a fat tourist imposing my presence at a not particularly happy place.
fascinating. fascinating insight into the culture without being "gross" or morbid. we could have stayed for hours as it was really interesting.

One of the most interesting and memorable experiences I've had. If you are only going to see one thing while in Kathmandu, make sure it is the Crematoria. It, and the surrounding Hindu temple complex, is a moving and memorable experience. We had an amazing young guide who brought us around and told us about the history of the place, and the Hindu traditions associated with cremations. We witnessed three different cremations while we were there, including one of a well-known local politician. We spent an hour and a half around the entire complex, but it felt like only ten minutes and we were both disappointed when the tour was over. I will never forget the time I spent there.Well worth the entrance price.
may 2014. well worth a visit..we were fortunate to see the cremation of a Ghurka with all the pomp and ceremony. many Hindu worshippers visiting the temple which is not open to non hindu.
Spirituality. While we never visited this place on purpose, it was found by accident, it was a very moving and spiritual experience. While not for everyone still worth a visit.

Eye opener. This place is a must see for anyone interested in the culture or Hindu religion. The place is open to Hindus 24 hours and people from all over come to cremate their loved ones. There was one happening while we were there and was fascinating.

Very Interesting. While it may not be for everyone, i was fascinated. The rituals and attention to family are amazing. Go with a guide that can explain what is happening and you will get much more from the visit.
Rush to see. Its the place to see burning dead body of Hindu people.Whats a Great culture totally different then others.its the place to see fear and unhappiness of NepaliHindu People.

Morbid, an eye opener of Hindu culture. This place is Nepal's most renowned cremation site. It was our first time witnessing burning of body in the open. In Hindu culture, after the person is dead, his/her dead body is wrapped in cloth and placed on bamboo litter and body are delivered by barefooted pallbearers accompanied by the deceased's male relatives. The body has to be cremated within 24 hours. The eldest son of the family performs the cremation ceremony. The cries of the family members were heart-wrenching. Even though I don't know them, my tears fell and at that moment I felt strange and awkward taking pictures of the ceremony. A few hours later the ashes were collected and swept in the river. The five elements (metal, wood, water, fire, earth) united to form a human body. When a dead body is cremated in fire, the element returns to nature.

Great cultural exposure.. A must experience to understand the culture. You can sit on the other side of the river and watch the cremations, without feeling like you are interfering in the rituals. Humbled and privileged to have experience it.
Gruesome, but fascinating. This is an opportunity to view and (with a good guide) understand the Hindu approach to death, and its associated rituals.
Cremetoria. Found lots people watching the dead bodies being burned and then parts of burned body collected and remainder is pushed into the river.
Sobering. What a glimpse into another culture. I felt privileged to experience it. Use a guide. The one we had was fantastic! We met him at the ticket booth.

public crematorium. Unexpectedly, this was a highlight of my Kathmandu city tour! I've never seen or heard of anything like it. I don't want to say too much to spoil it, but I'm a nurse and found it fascinating. I can see where it wouldn't be for everybody, but I view death as another stage of life and I like that the Nepali people seemed to view it the same way.

dont listen to those stupid people complaining about 10usd. some hippies just want to get everything for free.... its not like that.....it costs 10usd but, its really interesting and if you TRY TO TAKE PICTURES in GANGES river in varanasi you ll get in trouble coz the police andthe scammers work together there to catch tourirsts trying to take pict of the cremationin kathmandu pictures are allowed.... if you just want to see and not take pics go to varanasi its much bigger ... but if u want to take pics go to this one in nepal

Not something to enjoy, but go anyway. It's hard to give a rating to something that doesn't rate as entertainment. Watching the activities at the crematoria provides an opportunity to contemplate the rituals surrounding death, and the differences between cultures. This is certainly somewhere I wouldn't take the children unless you're ready for a very serious conversation. I'm glad I went.

Thought provoking. I didn't know what to expect, having read reviews describing the Cremation areas as "confronting and disturbing". I visited with my 25 year old daughter, and whilst the concept of sitting quietly watching the cremation formalities and rituals across a small canal seemed intrusional (and difficult to explain to others), we found it to be a thought provoking and contemplative experience. There are two cremation areas - basic platforms and "no frills" for commoners, and an area for more affluent people, with more ceremony and ritual.There was no sign of grief or drama, as the cremations seemed to be conducted more as a final formality and farewell before rebirth.A most worthwhile visit, which gives an enhanced understanding of local culture and thought. At no stage did our presence feel unwelcome or out of place - we were simply observers (amongst a few hundred others) quietly observing part of life's cycle.An important part of the Kathmandu "experience".

Interesting.. Very different from what we are used to in the western culture. It can be a little too much and a bit shocking. We have seen the crematorium at Varanasi, but somehow this was more memorable. Here you can see the ritual step by step and although you are watching from the other side of the river you can see all the details.

An experience I still can't wrap my brain around!. I don't think I would go here two times but the one time was a must! WOW! Interesting to learn about other cultures and this was certainly no exception!!!!

Memorable. This is Pashupatinath Temple and the sights you see here will stay in your mind for a long time after you have left. Death and grieving are on display in a way very different to western culture. You might feel slightly uncomfortable watching the events going on here. It is almost factory like with its efficiency. A body takes 3 hours to burn and they get through about 30 per day. You will see grieving families washing bodies in the Bagmati River. People draped in white or gold robes. It is all very symbolic. Have respect and don't get too close with your cameras and keep quiet. Tourists watch from the opposite side of the river. Sadhus or Holy Men in all their Technicolour glory will pose for photos if given 15Rs.

A very different experience. So, this was a very ... different ... experience, and it's not for everyone. The smell of the smoke stayed in my hair/clothes after (but, so does everything in Kathmandu).You could watch the rituals taking place before the cremations. It was a bit strange to watch people's grief as a tourist attraction, and I therefore refrained from taking pictures. None the less, it's a very interesting thing to see if you are not from a Hindu country.I still felt weird about watching this, but I think most people from countries where bodies are not publicly burned would feel weird about this.I'd be very interested to know how the families feel about tourists coming here for a cultural experience.

Check First. We visited this UNESCO World Heritage site as a part of a day tour when we first arrived in Kathmandu. We valued the cultural ritual of this ancient site but were unprepared for the open grief and confronting scenes we were privy to. Ask your tour guide if it is on the tour and perhaps read a little about it before going there. We were so wrapped up in our pending EBC trek that we had not given this site too much thought. I was haunted by the young woman who had lost her husband and her grief stricken cries. So public yet so very personal.
The cycle of life. The timeless ritual of farewell, ashes to ashes and return to the waters of life. Take the time to watch and reflect......

Fascinating. This was the most different experience we had while in Nepal. The customs are very different from those in the west. The complex itself is massive and very ornate. You'll note that many locals hang out here to see how cremations are done, since not all places in Nepal cremate. It was at times sacred, profane and sublime! Don't miss it.

Moving experience. I wish I had planned more time for the visit as watching a Hindu funeral in progress was a touching experience. There was so much happening and there was so much to see around the temple we wished we had scheduled a lot more time for our visit. There is the official tourist office opposite the home for the elderly so be sure you book a guide from them.

hire a local guide, be respectful, and you'll be enlightened. Very interesting visit, and informational. A local tour guide gave us the historical background and insight in the rituals, and found it to be quite educational. The overall grounds are impressive, as are the temples. The hillside is a great place to lounge, and though it's a bit awkward being among those dealing with such grief, it is also very important to understanding parts of their religion and culture. Very, very important and historical place.

odd mix of a tourist trap and holy temple. it is a functioning crematorium with families mourning recent past family members. It felt odd going to see a cremation with crying families and having it treated like a show with people taking pictures.i was uncomfortable there and did not stay long.

A Unique Experience. What a strange and unique experience for a Westerner! Certainly a memorable moment of our Kathmandu sightseeing journey. 100% worth visiting on the way through to Pashupatinath Temple.

Very interesting experience. It is such an experience to see the Crematoria especially if it is a first time like mine...of course you don't only see you also smell as the deceased person burns for several hours. Definitely worth to visit. It is as interesting as temples if not more...
Very intensive experience. All that smoke, dead bodies, dying bodies, flowers, food, and stories may start your mind reflecting on everything you can and even cannot imagine. Astonishing.

Unmissable but a little ghoulish - a privilege to observe. We couldn't take our eyes off what was happening, it's not something you see every day in the Western world, but a privilege to observe. We felt a little ghoulish though and intruders on other people's pain, but we were amongst 1000's observing the daily rituals. Go with a guide to explain the intricacies of life and death and ceremony in Hindu Kathmandu.

cremation ghats. 1st come here when i was 18! all i can say,after seeing this i deal with death easier,bodies in the open being cremated where as over here its grim coffins! :-( its very peace full there and when i die would like to be cremated there!!

Hold your breath. First thing was the smoke and it is hard to to breath it. The whole thing is exotic and kind of freakish. Not a religious person at so it was all lost on me. Interesting non the less. Could not get past the pollution of the air and river. Also even here locals throw garbage everywhere. One of those things worth seeing though

May cause culture shock. This site is fascinating, may not be appropriate for children. One of the most importand Hindu temples in the world. Non-Hindus are not allowed in the temple but can tour the grounds. Behind the temple is the crematorium where bodies are brought for their final purification ceremony of being burned on a funeral pyre. All this is out in the open. Lots of monkeys and religious pundits willing to let you take their picture (tips required!).

Cremation. This is a gruesome area & 1000's were there to see the many burials that were taking place.We witnessed the cremation of an old lady,from strategy to finish?Many relatives were there to see her cremation & after dropping her body (very heavy lady) the men eventually placed her body on the pyre,where the Priest set about starting the fire that quickly roared into life.Red flames shot up through the straw placed on the body to help the wood & body burn effectively.Whilst it was gruesome it was all completed in a very dignified way.Her son was the one who lit the fire & he had to be helped by a number of other relatives as he was near collapse.If you have a queasy stomach - Don't Go.Neither my partner or I want to see another cremation of this kind.

A bit expensive for a funeral. It was culturally interesting to see the corpse being prepared for cremation and if you have not been to Varanasi, you may well be impressed. Otherwise, apart from some entertaining Saddhus, all of whom spoke excellent English there is nothing much there for a non-Hindu because you cannot visit the Temple.At $10 per person plus taxi there and back it does seem to offer less value than many other places in Nepal.And dont forget that you can visit some of the most beautiful Buddhist temples for free!

Cycle of Life. There are three different listings on Trip Advisor for the Pashupatinath Temple complex, but I chose to submit a review under this heading since the most interesting aspect for me was observing the Hindu ritual of cremation. If you spend a significant amount of time here, you are likely to witness all stages of the ritual....This has been going on thoughout generations of Hindus, but I noticed one radical modern aspect...when one man was using his smartphone to record a video of the deceased as they set the cremation fire.Westerners can expect to pay a relatively high fee to gain access to the complex, but it's worth the price to gain a deeper understanding of the culture.

Interesting..... Very interesting to see but still felt like an intruder upon people's private grief. Found the experience more natural than Varanasi. Some interesting ??? People around the place made it an experience not to be missed.

An insight into Hindu funeral traditions. Visiting the "ghats" (cremation sites) by Pashupatinath temple is a very interesting experience. It is important for cultural understanding and fascinating to learn about Hindu believes. Most Hindus in Nepal are cremated here, provided they can reach Pashupatinath within 24 hours of death. There is a hospice nearby, which allows people to die within reach of this sacred place. Take your time visiting (and watching) this area and respect the families.
An experience not to be missed.. This is the reality for end of life for many Hindus. Part of our trip was cultural understanding and this was an important part.
Life and Death. Take a walk along the river to watch cremation ceremonies that are certain to change your perspective on life. Local Hindus are preparing their loved ones for the transition process.

Interesting. This is an interesting and educational site to visit. I did have some reservation about visiting a place of sorrow and did not want to be intruding on others bereavement . You are kept to the opposite side of the river to where the bodies are and you are not intruding. It's not a pleasant place but interesting. There are a number of holy men sitting in the area who will allow you sit with them for a photo for a small donation. There are also numerous monkeys in the area.

an insight into a different cultural attitude to death and dying. It did make me think a lot to visit this site. We had a Hindu guide who explained the context for the cremations and the rituals involved. I think it is advisable to have a guide definitely worth it. I wasn't too comfortable with cremations as a spectator sport and particularly the cameras and photographs aspect of it - feels too intrusive and disrespectful. However if you are prepared for what you are seeing you can learn more about the Hindu way of dealing with death and maybe think about our own more private ceremonies too.
so particular. we arrived at sunset the last day for us in Nepal.... some body burned, smell, some people started puja...the ticket costs 1.000 rs little bit expencive

Soon to be eliminated ?. A fascinating area to view the daily ceremonies and cremations of the deceased.After the pyre has burned down, the remains are pushed into the holy Bagmati River. Note the men searching the river bed for valuables.

Interesting!. It didn't seem to be either intrusive or mawkish to watch cremations taking place at the Ghat on the other side of the river. As our guide explained, they have a very different opinion of death than us. In fact, he questioned why we do everything so - in his opinion - secretly and never seem to discuss the manner of a persons death. Here it is all so open so people visiting here should be aware of exactly what they will see. It is all carried out so matter of factly so totally acceptable to witness - all part and parcel of witnessing life in Nepal.
Freaky. I saw some old man get cremated and then ashes pushed into the river. Same river some kids were bathing and playing in. Amazing thing to see, if you can cope with this sort of stuff

Enthralling. I had never seen such a sight before and I was stunned. You will be across the river, but you will have a clear view of cremation ceremonies being performed. I was respectful as it was apparent that the families across the river were in mourning. It provided me great insight to the Hindu religion and the local culture. The overall area is in poor condition but you have to remember that Nepal is a very poor country and conditions like that are common. If you think you would feel strange in viewing such an event, you should not visit this site.
Incredible, educational. Fascinating, very impressive! We expected it to be "creepy" to watch, but it is not, instead it gave us a completely different point of view of life

Fascinating and educational. This is a must see... you can learn so much about the culture, the people and the religion. Don't go the the cremation site itself, really that can be a bit grim to be so close to it all, and somewhat intrusive, but g across the other side of the river and sit opposite the cremation pyres there you can see everything and all the rituals without imposing on the mourners.

Interesting. I had heard that the Hindu religion required cremation but it was really brought home when we observed several cremations in various stages. We were also privileged to watch the ceremony for a gentleman that was being prepared for his cremation. Very interesting and educational.

Could have given it a pass.. Not really a tourist attraction as such. These are open cremations on the side of a dirty river. The place was very smokey and the temple is off limits for non-hindus. You could sit and watch a cremation happen if that's your sort of thing.The entrance price was 1,000 rupees which I found to be very steep. I thought I'd see it since I'm already in Nepal. Wasn't very educational or special.

So interesting to see how other cultures view death!. First of all, I must say I agree with a previous review that the Crematoria is a sacred place which has nothing morbid about the Hindu practice of cremation and what it embodies. It provides a unique sight, rarely experienced by Westerners. The Crematoria is within the complex of the Pashupatinath Temple. A fascinating site, an open air crematorium where you can learn about the Hindu way of dealing with the departed ones; a large and well kept ancient complex of temples, stupas, and old buildings sitting on the river Bagmati where a traveller can get a good eye-view of the cremation process of a Hindu believer. Also an interesting place to learn a bit about the Hindu and Nepali culture. Ceremony: Impossible to describe it! You need to prepare yourself for this experience and be aware that you might find what you see difficult for the Western eye (Western sensibility can be deeply touched as it can be a bit disturbing for Western eyes). Bodies are brought here within the first few hours of death to be cremated; all the family gather round and help to prepare the bodies before they are cremated. According to the rank of the dead person, the body is cremated in the respective ghat. Families share their grief, come together and prepare their loved one for the next journey. In this cultural and spiritual ceremony the feet of the bodies are unwrapped and washed in the holy waters of the above mentioned river. After that, bodies are decorated with flowers and powder. Some holy milk from the temple is poured into the dead’s mouth and after the performance of the family rituals, the bodies are placed on the fire stand (pyres). Bodies, covered in wood, take around 5 to completely cremate. Afterwards, the ashes are pushed and scattered into the holy river. Last but not least, young boys search the river waters for gold and other metals that did not burn.Westerners don't seem to accept death as part of living; Hindus see it as a sacred end. So, this is an excellent opportunity to learn about the Hindu way of returning and disposing the "empty shell" (the human body) where it belongs to. Photography: cremations are a very moving affair. Observed all the goings with due respect and decorum, discreetly. I took no photos, as I felt it was rude to intrude. I hate tourists who despite being told not to take photos take their huge zoom lens intruding into families’ grief. It is really irritating for me to observe those who clearly prioritize a photo to show the friends and relatives back home than to a human being's pain.If you choose not to pay the entrancee fee, as a non-Hindus you may observe the cremations and preceding ceremonies from a close vantage point across the river. Absolutely worthwhile as they are so different from our closed doors burials! Not for the faint of heart, though. One may feel terribly impressed here. An amazing cultural, touching and spiritual experience! A heart moving site to the Western traveller. An interesting glimpse of another culture. A cultural curiosity, an eye opener. Not confronting, just outside our experience. I really learnt a lot.Give yourself ample time and indeed hire a site guide (some with faultless English) who may have much to offer (Non Hindus normally may not get to see these rituals anywhere else. I would strongly advise a guide for a better and further understanding and appreciation of Hindu way of life). Great to see how another religion deals with death. Absolutely worthwhile if you want a cultural lesson, a learning experience. Not for the light – hearted as I said before. A life experience! I felt privileged. Touching, moving. A deeply recommended spiritual place. Certainly educational, indeed. A must see to understand this ancestral culture! Westerners, watch out! We have much to learn!
