Most Interesting site. From the title I am assuming this is the temple complex and crematorium on the river where the Golden Temple is. Anyway this is a large and very well kept ancient complex of temples, stupas, and old buildings and sits on the river. The Golden temple is on a hill overlooking the river. This is a fascinating site because you can watch and even photograph the city's dead as they are washed and prepared for cremation. A little further along on the river are the cremation pyres and you can follow the procession of the body from the washing to the cremation. It is a large site to explore and some of the buildings sit along a gorge so it is very scenic too. It is similar to Varanasi in India but this place is far better kept and far more beautiful.
Open air Crematorium. Worth the visit as you get a glimpse of the differences in culture.There were two funerals whilst we were there

Hindu way of dealing the departed. This (at the Lord Pasupathinath Temple Kathmandu) is a very rare unique place where one can see and study the Hindu way of returning and disposing the "empty shell" (the human body) where it belongs-that is the 5 elements of this earth. Pending the rank of the departed, the body will be cremated in the respective Ghat. Any one can observe all the goings with due respect and decorum. Non Hindus normally may not get to see these aspects any where. I would strongly advise a guide (pay NRs 500/0) to give a running commentary on the rituals, their meanings and significance of them for a better understanding and appreciation of Hindu way of life. A visitor will always cherish such a visit to this place in the Pasupathinathf Temple.
Fascinating. A fascinating view into how another culture deals with death in a practical and public way. Best seen and explained by a guide which will be cost you about 1000 NPR.

Cremations!! My first and last time. How do I begin this... It was the first time during my stay in Nepal that I smelled beef barbecue...That's how bad it was... We watched everything. How the ceremony begins, how the monks sitting by the river sides do consultations for money, how the people bathe in the holy river while cremations are ongoing, all sort of animals are in the river as well. It's a mess. Wouldn't go there again.

Watch Your Step. This stop is a must, as the traveler will get a good eye-view of the cremation process of a Hindu believer. But do watch your step, as my companion stepped in a huge cow patty freshly dropped. Made a mess of his shoe.

Cremations. You need to prepare yourself for this experience and be aware that you might find what you see difficult . We visited during the monsoon so the river was higher than usual. Interesting, but I felt it was a touch intrusive for my western sensibilites although it prompted good discussion of Hindu beliefs.

public creamation in full view!. Interesting place to go to learn a bit about the Hindu and Nepali culture. The river was at a trickle and full of trash when we were there. Saw a ceremony from the other side of the river where people were dipping the body into the river. Very eerie and felt a bit like we're intruding. We did not following when they took the body to get creamated. Saw a large group of monkeys while we were there. The place was not too crowded when we were there at the end of the day.

interesting. A shock for those that are not prepared but very interesting. To watch a burning in the way that it is conducted is very interesting and I have been several times now and taken different people with me on each occasion.A great insight to the way Nepal works and its culture.

important cultural site. Witnessing the hindu cremations was interesting and humbling. A cool glimpse into another culture.
just be careful of pickpockets on a crowded day.

Funeral rites. This might not be for the faint of heart. So interesting to see the preparations for the cremating of the dead and how the families share their grief with the onlookers on the other side of the river. Young rascals paddle in the river to grab anything of value thrown into the water.

Very interesting. The river was very low when we were there which made for a vivid impression. We watched parts of some ceremonies from the bridge. We had school age children there with us so there was a lot of good discussion on how different cultures and religions do things.
Three Sisters. How interesting was that had a lengthy stay here and couldn't believe what we saw. I am very glad that we are not in that culture
Fascinating. This was an experience like no other. Make sure you allocate at least an hour to observe and learn about the public cremations.

Far Better Spiritual Holy Places in India - But Good For Beginners.. .I accept my feelings may not be as strong as others as I've visited far better holy places in India and seen the funeral pyres in more dramatic settings. Once again, if you've been to somewhere like Varanasi then you're not going to be terribly impressed here.The first thing that hits you is that there's hardly any water in the river - this is apparently due to the Nepalese goverment - so we were told. So you've got a fairly empty river filled with sand bags trying to direct the trickle of water that's left. And what you're left with is stagnant polluted water filled with ashes and debris which should be flowing away 'to a better world' - but is actually only travelling a few metres. It's not exactly the Ganges.Despite tourists being told not to take photos of those that have died, you'll still probably be irritated by someone with a huge zoom lens intruding into a families grief. Clearly it's better for some to get a photo to show the folks back home than care about someone's pain.Guides will most likely take you here in the daytime - but there is no atmosphere. You really want to be here from around 7pm when there's music and chanting and various other rituals. Only then will you experiece some magic.What I found incredibly sad about this place - and a real wake-up call - was to see children glue-sniffing, and others chain-smoking. It is quite bizarre to see families in grief with the loss of a loved one, while amongst them are kids sniffing glue out of polythene bags, and their parents high on other substances. It would appear that this is a place where those that are hooked on substances also come to sleep at night, as to be honest, I've not seen these people here in the daytimes. So it's your call when you would prefer to visit.I love to see the sadhus - but please accept that the sadhus here are fakes - these are people who dress up to make money out of tourists. But that's fine as long as you accept what's going on. Regardless, they make great photos.Also, if you are not a Hindu then you have to accept you're not going to see the best of what is available. You will not be allowed inside the best temples. So really you're only getting a peek of what is available and going on.If I had not been to far better holy places I would have scored this area higher, as this is exactly the type of experience I like to have in such countries. But the truth is that there are better places, more spiritual places, and more atmospheric places. And ALL of them come alive at night. But if this is your first holy place it's not a bad for a starter, but it is rather limited. PLUS, this is the only holy place I've been to in the world where I've had to pay an entry fee - and a high one at that. Shame the Nepalese goverment aren't plowing all the money they are making out of tourists and putting it back into the community...

We were privileged.... On the day our party went to visit, we were privileged to see a Gurkha cremation. It was a very moving affair, with a salute from his regiment. I took no photos, as I felt it was rude to intrude, but being able to pay my own respects as a UK citizen, to one of the bravest regiments in British history,was my pleasure.The area is quite small compared to Varanassi and ceremonies are less formal than our own funerals, but no less significant. Be careful that you observe the wind direction, as it can blow cremation smoke right across the river and into everyone's eyes.

Public Crematorium. This was a life experience.....we were only there for 2 hours and 4 bodies were bought to be cremated. We were spectators to a very real, touching, moving, cultural and spiritual ceremony for cremating their dead.The feet of the bodies were unwrapped and washed in their holy water (what we saw was a squalid, dirty and rubbish strewn river) and yet this was their holy water. The bodies were dressed, de-robed discretely, robed again and decorated with flowers and powder. The holy milk from the temple was poured into the mouth of the dead and after the family rituals were performed, the bodies were placed on the fire stand, whereby fire was placed in the mouth and the body set alight, covered in wood and left to cremate for approx. 5 hours before the entire pile of burnt wood, ash etc was then pushed into the holy river.An amazing cultural experience!!!!
Crematorium. Really interesting. Exposure to another culture.interesting to see opportunity to have photos with local priest.again relax and spend as much time as you like
Cultural experience. A must see to understand this ancestral culture where the long ritual unify the family around the lost one. This is touching and very spiritual experience.

Different culture. You will visit the holly place where deads are cremated and stop reencarnations... You have to know what you are going to isit.. You will see the bodys and also smell them meanwhile they are cremated.. If you havn't been before in Varanassi just be prepared

Some people may enjoy the cult. I did not.. That is where families have the bodies of dead relatives washed at a dirty river, then burned at open air and the ashes thrown at the river afterwards. Not a good sight and a very bad smell. Hussain Said Mourad
interesting religious place. It is nothing WOW, but it was worth to pass by and see the religious building. You cannot go in, but observe from the outside.

extraordinary experience. What an honor it was to experience this place. While we were there a cremation was taking place and a sevite was preparing for the evening Arati. The Sadhus were in place and more than willing to be photographed...prepare to pay them 100 rupees and they are very happy to let you click away.

Very unexpected. During our sightseeing tour we were taken to the Bagmati river and really had no idea what we were about to see. We talked with many locals along the way until we came upon lots of smoke. A local man than proceeded to explain that what we were looking at was in fact a cremation. He explained the beliefs, the procession and the family involvement in such a way we were really caught in the moment. His English was faultless and the amount of knowledge given kept our attention. Whether or not you decide to use the services of a guide is a personal choice but in this case it really turned out to be of great benefit. A sad but unique place to visit that came totally unexpected.

A heart moving site. Very unitque site along the river to view the cremations of deceased Hindus - with all the ritual involve. You will need to buy an entrance ticket. The you will be approached and pestered by men who want to be your guide for a few rupees. Recommend not to say a single word when asked ''where you come from''. One of them followed us constantly around, greatly diminishing the pleasure viewing this place.
Cremation. If you must see it, spend only a little time. It can bring back bad memories. It is a truly different way to bury your family

Interesting to the western traveler. Yes, there are really outdoor cremations here. Non-Hindus may observe the cremations, and preceding ceremonies from a close vantage point across the river. For the western traveler it is all an interesting glimpse of another culture. Small entry fee required.

A place to see. You have to see it , to understand how is the way to the other world in Nepal. Sometime you really feel unconfortable , watching the cremation process , and the intimity of the families.

Next to the Pashupatinah Temple. While you will only be able to see the outside of the temple, you will be able to view the Crematoria. It is immediately adjacent to the temple and you can observe what takes place by simply crossing the river and standing opposite the Crematoria. You will still be able to observe what is happening, but will be far enough away to not interfere with what is happening and more importantly not offend.Standing on the opposite side you can observe and take pictures / video as you like. Simply do so with quiet and respect.

Didn't want to go here. It really seems like this place shouldn't be opened to tourists. It's very strange that the burning/passing over of bodies to the next life is done in such a public/pay for entry way.
I don't really recommend tourists "intruding" on this place. It's just like tourists rocking up to your local cemetery and watching a burial.

Could be a bit disturbing for Western eyes.. What an amazing, spiritual place. It was a trifle unsettling for us as Westerners but we travel to experience new and different things and this was certainly educational. Not confronting, just outside our experience. Definitely recommend it.

Interesting and worth visiting. This is a sacred place to the nepalese and I found it very interesting and beautiful. Its worth reading a little bit about their cremation traditions before going. Also, there are several palm readers in the area which can be an interesting and fun experience. But i suggest having a guide as you will need translation.
Creepy. Unless you're into the macabre, there are better things to do. While family members grieve, tourists gawk from nearby. It's unseemly.

Take time to reflect here. This site has a foreigner entry fee, so despite it being very sacred and intimate, it is open to outsiders. I recommend hiring a driver who is willing to wait while you experience this riverside crematorium. Be respectful with photography, as families are having services for their loved-ones. Enjoy the sacred monkeys an cows ambling along the water. Sit at the river's edge and reflect, walk the temples, see the sadhus. Many younger locals will offer to guide you through this site for a fee, but I recommend just taking in the Crematoria silently and solely.

Nothing "Morbid" About It. The Crematoria is a sacred place. There's nothing "morbid" about the Hindu practice of cremation and what it embodies. The Crematoria is located within the larger complex of the Pashupatinath Temple. We went not knowing anything about the site, but a young, polite, well spoken Nepalese student came up to chat. I expected he'd eventually tell us he worked as a guide and would ask if we would like him to explain the site. He was such a nice kid we agreed and spent the next several hours learning about the temples and the Hindu practice of cremation. We saw nothing remotely close to what one reviewer suggested might be considered "morbid". Male members of families genitally wash the body of their love one following a sacred protocol and move it to where the spirit is released by cremation. Male sons perform the sacred rights which include them entering the temple after cremation and remaining in solitude for 13-days. One year from the sacred passage the they return to perform a second period of solitude. It is not possible to watch without feeling heartfelt sorrow for the families and reflect on the more typical western approach to burial where we saturate our love ones with formaldehyde, place them in a box and lock their spirit 2 metres underground. Soaring with eagles makes more sense. We have much to learn. The site is large, give yourself ample time and indeed hire a site guide they have much to offer.

Biggest BBQ in Kathmandu!!. If you've ever wondered about cremation ceremonies, then this place will answer every question you ever had. Not for the squeemish or the timid, this place can hit all new levels of what you might consider morbid, or dark...You will see people being cleansed in the river, adorned with colorful paints and chalk, prayed upon, and then put on fire and burned to ashes.

Need a guide to appreciate this place. Not usually a place on the tourist trek, but a friend of a friend died while I was in Kathmandu and got cremated there, so I understood some more about the people and their customs after having been to this holy place. It puts death into the perspective of life.

JDE0911. I found this place very interesting. The night I went there, there were prayers with three priests with fire and chanting with the people congregated there. It was very respecful and peaceful. There were a lot of people when I went and a few cremations underway. The only things is with the dust and the smoke in Kathmadu at the moment it was a all a bit polluted....
Higher understanding. Observing the cremation process will lead you to really give yourself a thought about your own belief system.
The Crematoria. Put your "big boots" on for this one. The river is extremely polluted and it is difficult watching the young boy who trolls the water for coins near the cremations.

Unique Experience. If you are in Kathmandu, take advantage of this experience. There are probably very few places in the world you can see this. The air quality is poor due to the constant burning, and you will come away with your clothes smelling awful. But the cremation process is extremely interesting.

Glad I went but I felt uneasy being there.. It was a unique experience but I felt uncomfortable intruding on a family's grief. Our guide took us there. We were on the other side of the river from the cremations. I got some good photos of "holy" men in bright orange dress on the tourist's side of the river.

A unique experience. I didn't fully understand where our guided tour was going and so this place was quite a shock. It did feel wrong and intrusive to have a crowd of picture taking tourists watching multiple ongoing funerals. The bodies are placed on a pedestal and covered by flowers. After the family has said their goodbyes, a worker covers the body with straw, kindling and firewood, then lights it up. Watching these bodies burn is a unsettling affair, and definitely not for the sqeamish. Although it sounds odd, the worst part for me was how they treated the "holy" river. The worker casually throw all the sticks, plastic bags, and all sorts of garbage in the water forming a huge cesspool, then they sweep the people's ashes into the same mess.
...unique. sounds, smells and sights - you get an overload charge, but that's the point of being there as a tourist
great place to see how bodys are cremated. great place to sit, relax and reflect as bodies are brought down and cremated. the place is big and there is plenty and room to visit temples close by

Disturbing to intrude on families grief. A very rare experience which I am glad I visited but felt rather uncomfortable throughout the visit.We had an unasked for guide who we didnt want and who complained bitterly that my tip was too small!There were several cremations taking place at the time of my visit and the air was redolent of scented woods used for the cremationsThe sacred river was a cess pit of the detritus of Kathmandu and my one question to the unwanted guide was why surely if this place was so sacred to them why on earth did they not at least clean up the section running through the temple. He chose not to answer!

Definitely go unless you're squeamish. You can'tbe thereforalong time, as the smokeis quite dense during most of the day, but it's an experience not to be missed. This is different from what you see in other places like Varanasi in India, so well worth going. It's very important to be respectful and not take pictures from close up. A good guide is also very useful, as there are specific rituals that are important to know about as you watch it.

a unique sight, rarely experienced by Europeans. A smaller albeit more comprehendable institution then in Varanasi, this site depicts the local burial customs, gives a unique smell to the ceremony, amidst an ancient great temple setting, gorgeous complex.

Macabre. If you are queemish Don't go there. Although interesting part of the Hindu culture. I felt it was too confronting and the river where they empty the ashes was filthy. 100 metre from where the ashes were tipped people were searching for "treasure" in the form of gold from jewelry and teeth

WOW. I witnessed the entire process of the Hindu cremation. I found it fascinating how the body is "processed", the way the family mourns, the idea that the ashes fall in to the Gangues and the eye candy of all the Hindu priests dressed in all their colour! If you go to Kathmandu, spend time here to appreciate the religion.
crematoria. nice architecture but awful smell of burning wood (and whatever else!). Felt a bit awkward - like gatecrashing someone's funeral.

Wow. Sitting across the river watching families say goodbye and cremate their loved ones is quite weird for someone from the West but it a strangely intimate and humbling experience.
Beware the so called holy men - they are simply beggars chancing their arm with gullible travellers.

We loved the monkeys, the monks and the architecture up on the hill above. The crematorium was interesting and many bodies were being cremated including a military cremation, but we liked wandering up the hill best. So many baby monkeys and the long-haired old monks sitting outside the small buildings that were so perfectly aligned was interesting.
Seeing a person cremated is intense!. This is a very intense experience if you happen upon an actual cremation. This could be very violent looking to young people.

This was an eye-opener!. so interesting. They actually were cremating people in shrouds while we and many others watched. They burned the people on these concrete stands, then swept their ashes into the river. Then young boys searched the river for gold and other metals that did not burn.
Very Interesting. A eye opening experience. Be prepared. We enjoyed it. Life and death all right in front of your eyes.

impressive. you should not bring your children there... even us were awkward...
But this is another culture and it's intersting to see bodies burning on the shore of the river...
Not for the light hearted. Watched several bodies being prepped then burned (although they are wrapped in cloth). Fasinating part of the culture. Worth the visit............

Creepy!. The way they cremated the people seemed like a nice ceremony to begin with but, by the time they were all ashes - the family have left and there's a lone man sweeping the remains into the river where a few meters down-river there are people washing their clothes. There were a few con jobs there, pick pockets and the like. The 'saints' that offered to have a picture with you (and then ask you for money after!!) weren't particularly nice and other people throwing rice at you and giving you an unasked for 'blessing' - which they then ask you to pay for too. The creepy men taking pictures of you were the worst part and the poor mentally afflicted weren't what I would call a prime part of the attraction.I would NOT go unless you are really really really really interested in the Hindu culture!

Eye opening. Growing up as a Catholic I guess I always just thought people were either buried or cremated behind closed doors. Going here was a real eye opener as it allowed me to see how another religion deals with death. Bodies are brought here within the first few hours of death to be cremated, all the family gather round and help to prepare the bodies before they are cremated. Then they watch until the ashes are scattered into the river. It's strange to watch as I could not imagine myself being so hands on and involved, it was beautiful to see families come together and prepare their loved one for the next journey. While there you are told the significance of the river and the reasons for every step in the cremation. It really is beautiful to see. We did not stay for an entire cremation as they take up to around 4 hours but I'm definitely happy I went as it opened my eyes greatly to a different way of living and I really think it's something everyone should see for themselves
The crematoria ground. Thought Varanasi (India) on the Ganges was something, but this was so dirty, cows dog and burning people all together. if you;re stomach is not to strong don't go there.
Sad. Very interesting and sad, bodies are change to dust, seeing the whole ritual is very interesting
Some things should be left sacred.. I know different cultures celebrate life and death differently, but I could not bring myself to attend this event out of respect for the families of the dead.

An Experience. As a Christian I had reservations about visiting this place. It felt disrepectful to attend someone's burial and to watch someone being burned. However, I was able to see how the family participates throughout the ceremony and this is their way of dealing with death. An experience to see at least once.

Sounds gruesome --- but a beautiful ceremony. I had very mixed feelings. I was squeamish upon seeing the funeral pyre. Then I witnessed the beautiful ceremony and traditions unfold. It was a beautiful and intelligent way to say goodbye. See it.

Strange place to Visit.. Unfortunately, these burning ghats are within the Pashupatinath Temple, that is rather expensive to enter. And once here at the 'crematoria', you stand out vividly as an outsider watching something that probably should be left to the families. We were amazed at western tourists taking pictures, thinking what it would be like to have a throng of Hindu travelers show up at the graveside funeral of your own grandmother and start snapping pictures. It was just weird and creepy. I think it just added to the overall despair of the temple complex, the poor Bagmati River, and the sad caged deer at the other end of the temple border.
place full of emotions. I liked to see how families said good bye to their dead person. the simple ceremony is full of emotions. Contrast between life and death

Life, Death, Colour and Smoke. We were here with our teenage children. We are all used to the third world and confronting death. This place is all you expect it to be. Yet another place in Nepal that makes you contemplate your mortality and place in the universe. You feel a little voyeuristic watching other peoples grief. Yet it does us good to see death in manner that is hidden in our society. Then there are the colorful hollywood holys looking for some money for a photo. Wafts of smoke, monkeys everywhere, cremations going on, ashes being dumped in filthy polluted water.Local on lookers, crumbling ancient buildings...it's a place you need to visit. All part of the rich tapestry of life.
Very moving and sacred site. The significance of the site is powerful. There were several cremations taking place and it was very interesting to watch the processions.
crematoria plenty. you can see everyday crematoryu procesion, crematory working .iys so plentyposibilites

A best way to explore hindu cluture.. It was really interesting to visit this temple and is around. you have enough change to see cremation of death people directly and Nepali culture how the do when people die. you also could explore Pasupati temple or Crematoria from many ways.

By Crematoria, do you mean Pashupatinath Temple Complex and Funeral Ghats?. If this refers to the Pashupatinath temple complex, then calling it the Crematoria is a bit of an insult, as it is far more than just the place where many Kathmandu-ites receive their funeral rites. The temple itself is one of the holiest in Nepal and contains a 5-faced Lingum (admission to Hindus only). There is a deer park and many smaller shrines, lingums, chaityas and areas of interest. Watch out for the monkeys; they can be vicious if teased or offered food. Watch out for the sadhus -- they can be expensive if you take their photo.
Very moving. This is not a place to like but to respect. This part of the culture is so different from ours that I just had to stand and stare. Hopefully no-one noticed

Interesting.. Very morbid watching the families grieve and burning their loved ones. Did not enjoy this at all but that is only my view. River flowing past the Ghats heavily polluted and Yogis demanding money for photo's. Not a side of Nepal I would recommend.
A cultural lesson.. So interesting to see how other cultures view death. I really learnt a lot here.

This was a learning experience!. You learn the customs of other countries, and it is good to see the way other people see death.We don't seem to accept death as part of living, they see it as a sacred end. I, myself, would not drink the water where they buried the dead people. That part was a little repulsive to me.
A cultural curiosity. A place to see the funeral ceremony if you are interested. It can be observed discretly from the other side of the river.

Not for the faint of heart. The day we visited there where 5 platforms in use, after the fire is out the remains are shoveled into the river,people were also in the river looking for coins?A different culture for sure!
